THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        DLJ Mortgage Capital, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        Boyd Jones, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison R. Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-144
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 3, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Boyd J. Jones, of West Columbia, Pro Se, for Appellant.
        Stephen C. Lenker, Jr. and Weston Adams, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an appeal from an order of the circuit court enforcing a settlement agreement previously presented in open court.Â  We affirm.[1]
1.Â Â Â The parties appeared before the Honorable Garrison Hill for a motions hearing.Â  Prior to the hearing, however, the parties informed the court that they had reached a settlement agreement of all issues.Â  At that time, the terms of the settlement were presented in open court.Â  Immediately thereafter, Appellant was sworn in and testified to the terms of the agreement.Â  Appellant further assured the court he was freely and voluntarily entering into the agreement, free from any pressure or improper influence. Â At the urging of the parties, the court accepted the settlement on the record.Â  Subsequently, Appellant failed to sign the consent order reflecting the terms of the settlement previously agreed upon.Â  Respondent moved to enforce the settlement agreement. Â Judge Alison R. Lee heard this motion, and appropriately enforced the settlement agreement pursuant to Rule 43(k), SCRCP.Â  
We find Appellantâ€™s appeal utterly specious.Â  The transcript leaves no question that the matter was resolved.Â  Appellant testified under oath before Judge Hill that he agreed to settle the matter.Â  See Rule 43(k), SCRCP (â€œNo agreement between counsel affecting the proceedings in an action shall be binding unless reduced to the form of a consent order or written stipulation signed by counsel and entered in the record, or unless made in open court and noted upon the record.â€) (emphasis added).Â  
2. Â All other issues raised are manifestly without merit.Â  Accordingly, they are dismissed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Daisy Wallace Simpson, Respondent/Appellant,
        v.
        William Robert Simpson, individually and as shareholder/member of Simpson Farms, L.L.C. and William R. Simpson, Jr., 
          as a shareholder/member of Simpson Farms, L.L.C., Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-147
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 4, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Steven Smith McKenzie, of Manning, for Appellants-Respondents.
        C. Dixon Lee, James T. McLaren, Jan L. Warner, of Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  In this domestic action, William Robert Simpson (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order, arguing the family court erred in (1) failing to rule on his motion for a retroactive decrease in alimony and a return of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs; (2) its award of equitable distribution; (3) awarding his former wife, Daisy Wallace Simpson (Wife) alimony; (4) Â finding Husbandâ€™s yearly income is $150,000 per year; (5) its valuation of property; (6) characterizing him as not having cooperated in the discovery process; and (7) awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Wife also appeals the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS

Husband and Wife married in 1968, and resided in Clarendon County, South Carolina throughout the duration of the marriage.Â  When the couple first married, they bought a mobile home and lived on property owned by Husbandâ€™s father. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In 1971, Husbandâ€™s father died, and his will left a life estate in the Simpson family home to Husbandâ€™s mother, with the remainder to Husband.Â  Husband asked Wife to quit her job at a manufacturing plant in Manning to stay home with his mother.Â  The couple moved into the house and lived there throughout the remainder of the marriage.Â  Husbandâ€™s mother lived at the house for one year until she remarried.Â  Although Husbandâ€™s interest in the house did not fully vest until his motherâ€™s death in 1991, the couple substantially renovated the home.Â  Husband and Wife completed most of the renovations themselves.Â  The couple has three children. Two of the children are emancipated and the youngest was attending college at the time of the hearing.Â  Â Â 
During the marriage, Wife had several outside jobs but primarily stayed at home and took care of the family.Â  Husband became a successful farmer and land owner and eventually developed some of his land into residential lots.Â  Â Â Â 
In 1989, pursuant to a hand-written agreement between William Simpson, Jr., (Simpson, Jr.) and Husband, Simpson, Jr. began working for Husband.Â  The agreement provided that Simpson, Jr. would work on the family farm for $120 per week.Â  In exchange for his low salary, Husband would provide Simpson, Jr. with equity in the land and farm machinery.Â  In 2000, a month after Husband and Wife reconciled, Husband began to transfer most of the property he owned into Simpson Farms, L.L.C. (the LLC).Â  
The couple separated three times during the marriage.Â  The first separation occurred in the 1980â€™s and the second in 1999.Â  In 1999, the parties began formal litigation, but they reconciled in 2000.Â  The partiesâ€™ final separation occurred in 2003.Â  
After the parties reconciled in 2000, Wife began attending real estate classes and eventually earned her real estate license.Â  Husband did not approve of Wifeâ€™s pursuit of her real estate license and did not speak to her during this time.Â  Husband purchased and sold numerous properties, often using other real estate agents.Â  Â Â 
On March 4, 2003, Wife filed this action against Husband, the LLC, and Simpson, Jr.[1] Â Wife also requested, inter alia, separate support and maintenance, equitable division of the marital estate, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  At the temporary hearing, the family court ordered Husband to pay Wife $1,000 per month pendente lite spousal support.Â  Further, the family court ordered Husband to advance Wife $15,000 pendente lite attorneyâ€™s fees with the caveat that the family court could treat the fees as a credit toward Wifeâ€™s equitable apportionment at the final hearing.Â  
Most of the three day trial concerned the value of Husbandâ€™s vast property holdings and the amount of Husbandâ€™s income.Â  Husband testified he did not know exactly what he owned.Â  In many instances, the value Husband assigned to his properties and assets contradicted what he reported on his tax returns. Â Further, Husband testified the LLC never filed a tax return nor did it have an operating account. Â Although Husband denied selling his interest in S & T Land Developers (S & T) after litigation commenced, a deed dated March 10, 2003â€”six days after Wife instituted her actionâ€”showed that Husband transferred his fifty percent interest to Ray Tidwell for $5.Â  During trial, Wifeâ€™s expert testified the value of Husbandâ€™s fifty percent interest in S & T was $318,000.Â  Husband also testified that he pays Simpson, Jr. a different amount each year.Â  He could not recall what he paid his son the previous year.Â  
The family court found that Husband and Simpson, Jr. were not credible witnesses.Â  The family court based its decision, in part, on testimony of Husbandâ€™s witness, Tracy Amos, a certified public accountant. Â Amos admitted Husband undervalued assets, failed to report to her his antique car collection, and failed to report on his tax return a sale of timber for $40,000.Â  The family court found Husband repeatedly testified that he did not know what he owned. Â In his responses to discovery it appeared that he made â€œlittle effortâ€ to assist his lawyer or the court to identify what he owned.Â  The family court also found Husband testified that he purchased property with cash to assist sellers in avoiding taxation.Â  Ultimately, the family court found Husband tried to hide his true income and ultimately determined his income was $150,000, which was the amount he reported to banks and other lending institutions.Â

A. Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees & Costs
Wife argues the family court erred by not awarding Wife adequate attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses.Â  Further, Wife maintains the family court erroneously limited its consideration of the factor of â€œcustomary legal fees for similar servicesâ€ to the local geographic area where the trial was held.Â  Â 
The total marital estate in this case is valued at nearly $2.4 million.Â  Wife was awarded $1,000 per month in alimony, and her equitable share in the marital assets was $784,055.Â  Wife employed two attorneys from Columbia.Â  Her attorneys charged $400 per hour for their work, $200 per hour for associates, and $100 per hour for paralegal work.Â  Her two expert witnesses, Hobbs, the CPA, and Linhardt, the appraiser, charged $23,458.88 and $51,000, respectively, for their work in assessing and valuing the marital estate.Â  
Wife argues the family court abused its discretion by not giving sufficient consideration to Husbandâ€™s material misrepresentations, non-disclosure of income, and undervaluation of marital assets.Â  The court made numerous findings regarding Husbandâ€™s intentional non-disclosure of information and misrepresentations, including: 

  [Husbandâ€™s] Financial Declaration is not an accurate reflection of his spendable income . . . .Â  It is now clear to the [c]ourt that the Husbandâ€™s income and assets greatly exceed that which has been reported on his Financial Declarations. . . . I find that [Husband] has obfuscated his true income and assets . . . . [Husband] testified he purchased property with cash so that sellers could avoid taxation. . . . Based upon the swapping of money and property between Defendants Simpson Sr. and Simpson Jr., the discovery process has been significantly extended and confusion has reigned supreme. . . . I find as a fact that the credibility of the Defendants Simpson Jr. and Simpson Sr. are subject to significant question. . . . The demeanor of [Husband] while testifying before this [c]ourt and his own admissions as to some of his financial transactions raise questions in the [c]ourtâ€™s mind as to how open and honest he has been with [Wife] and the [c]ourt regarding his economic transactions. . . .

The record supports the family courtâ€™s conclusions that Husbandâ€™s behavior unnecessarily complicated this case.Â  It is important to remember when analyzing attorneyâ€™s fees that this Court does not sit to relieve self-inflicted wounds.Â  Rish v. Rish by and Through Barry, 296 S.C. 14, 17, 370 S.E.2d 102, 104 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Likewise, this Court looks unfavorably on cases, such as this one, where a party withholds information that is necessary for the proper adjudication of the matters under consideration.Â  Skipper v. Skipper, 278 S.C. 104, 106, 292 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1982).Â  Husbandâ€™s lack of cooperation in discovery forced Wifeâ€™s attorneys to obtain relevant information through other more difficult means.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 372 S.E.2d 107 (Ct. App. 1988) (Because Husbandâ€™s behavior caused Wife to incur additional expenses in the form of attorneyâ€™s fees at trial and on appeal, those expenses should be included in the family courtâ€™s determination of attorneyâ€™s fees on remand.).
In E.D.M. v. T.A.M., the South Carolina Supreme Court delineated the four factors used to determine whether attorneyâ€™s fees are warranted in a given case:

  (1) the partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee;
  (2) beneficial results obtained by the attorney;
  (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions;
  (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partiesâ€™ standard of living.

307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  Additionally, in Glasscock v. Glasscock, the South Carolina Supreme Court clarified the six factors used to determine a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee:

  (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case;
  (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case;
  (3) professional standing of counsel;
  (4) contingency of compensation;
  (5) beneficial results obtained;
  (6) customary legal fees for similar services.

304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
In the present case, we find the family court properly identified and applied the Glasscock factors until it considered the last factor, â€œthe customary legal fees for similar servicesâ€ factor.Â  The family courtâ€™s order reads â€œBased on the testimony of Ray E. Chandler, W.C. Coffey, Jr., and experience, I find that customary fees for similar work in this area is $185-$250 per hour.Â  Hourly fees that exceed this amount in this area are unusual rather than customary.â€Â  This conclusion is not supported by the record.Â  Ray Chandler, Husbandâ€™s former attorney, testified as follows:

  Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Ray, you say youâ€™ve been practicing law for twenty-seven years?
  A:Â Â Â Â Â  Iâ€™ve been practicing law for thirty-three years.Â  Iâ€™ve been practicing domestic law until last year when I have it up.Â  Twenty-seven, twenty-eight years.
  Q:Â Â Â Â Â  What were your rates when you gave up the good domestic practice per hour?
  A:Â Â Â Â Â  About two hundred and fifty dollars an hour in this county.
  Q:Â Â Â Â Â  What is your observation of the average rates of domestic fees in Clarendon, Lee, Williamsburg, in the Third Circuit, Sumter County?
  A:Â Â Â Â Â  I think the numbers that I see run between a hundred and sixty, seventy-five, eighty-five dollars.

Mr. Chandler did not testify as to the customary fees for a complex case such as this one.Â  W.C. Coffey never testified about rates whatsoever.Â  Instead, his testimony concerned the common practice of father-son farmer teams setting up LLCâ€™s in which to hold their land and equipment.Â  
On the other hand, the family court was presented with affidavits from Wifeâ€™s attorneys as well as attorneys Lon Shull III and Mark Taylor, all of whom testified that $400 per hour is a reasonable and customary rate in Clarendon County for family law experts who try complicated cases like the one at bar.Â  Our Supreme Court has approved the practice of considering attorneysâ€™ resumes or professional standing as well as attorneysâ€™ affidavits when deciding appropriate attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 385, 377 S.E.2d 296, 297 (1989).Â  Additionally, the court may consider whether the case was contested in good faith, whether the proof was simple or complicated because of the extent that material facts were disputed, and whether trial preparation by the attorneys required unusual skill, effort, or investment of time.Â  Prevatte v. Asbury Arms, 302 S.C. 413, 417, 396 S.C. 642, 644 (1990).
The record shows this was not an average case; rather it was a quite complex case which required unusual skill, effort, and time.Â  The family court was presented with testimony of four lawyers concerning customary fees for similar services in a complex case. Â However, the court relied on testimony of Husbandâ€™s former attorney who testified regarding average rates for a domestic case.Â  This was error.Â  Â Â 
Numerous cases in South Carolina list attorneyâ€™s fees charged in the locality for similar services as a factor to be considered in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See e.g., Blumberg v. Nealco Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (emphasis added); Meene v. Keowee Key Prop. Owners Assâ€™n Inc., 368 S.C. 557, 569, 629 S.E.2d 690, 697 (Ct. App. 2006); Rowell v. Whisnant, 360 S.C. 181, 185-86, 600S.E.2d 96, 99 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Therefore, we cannot assign error to the family courtâ€™s consideration of the local geographic area in determining the proper attorneyâ€™s fees. 
Accordingly, the portion of the family courtâ€™s order regarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is reversed and remanded for the family court to properly assess the facts of the case and the Glasscock factors in accordance with our decision. 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.[6]
ANDERSON, and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1] Wife named Simpson, Jr. as a defendant because he is a member of the LLC.
[2] This issue was not raised in Husbandâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion and would not have been preserved even if the motion had gone forward.Â  
[3] We also note that Simpson, Jr.â€™s tax return and his accumulation of assets cannot be reconciled.Â  For example, in 2001 he purchased $14,000 worth of real estate and his tax return showed an income of $17,000.Â  Despite a tax return never showing an income greater than $26,000, in 2003, Simpson, Jr. owned $150,000 worth of farm equipment.Â  
[4] This issue was not raised in Husbandâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  
[5] Husband did raise this issue in the Rule 59(e) motion, which the family court dismissed.Â  
[6] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        James A. McGee, Respondent,
        v.
        Monica Kay McGee, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Jeffrey Young, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-148
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 4, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        C. Vance Stricklin, Jr. and Katherine Carruth Link, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this family law action, Monica McGee (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order awarding her lump sum alimony of $250 per month for three years.Â  Wife claims lump sum alimony was not an appropriate type of alimony.Â  Further, she argues the actual amount of alimony was inadequate.Â  We affirm as modified. 
FACTS

Wife and James McGee (Husband) married on April 5, 1988, and had two children: Chelsea, born in 1991, and Alex, born in 1995.Â  In April of 2003, on the evening of their fifteenth anniversary, Husband informed Wife that he did not love her anymore.Â  However, Husband did not move out of the house until July 11, 2003.Â  
After moving out, Husband bought a condominium.Â  Kelly Gregory moved into Husbandâ€™s condominium following her separation from her husband.Â  Kelly and her husband had been neighbors and friends with both Husband and Wife, and their children were friends.Â  Kelly told her husband that she was living in Husbandâ€™s condominium as a roommate only.Â  
On July 29, 2003, Husband filed for a decree of separate support and maintenance.Â  On September 3, 2003, Wife filed an answer and counterclaim.Â  On June 14, 2004, Wife filed an amended answer and counterclaim requesting a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Husband amended his pleadings to seek a divorce on the ground of one-yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  
On November 30, 2004, the family court conducted a hearing.Â  Several witnesses testified that both Husband and Wife drank practically every night.Â  Husbandâ€™s witnesses testified that Wife drank as much or more than Husband.Â  Witnesses also testified to incidents where Wife displayed excessive anger.Â  David Gregory, Kellyâ€™s ex-husband, testified that after Wife learned about Kelly moving in with Husband, he found a computer monitor Wife borrowed from him broken in a field beside her house as well as some ski equipment he left at her house for a combined yard sale.Â  Another neighbor, Wolfgang Scheider, testified that he witnessed Wife pounding on the window of Husbandâ€™s truck and screaming at him.Â  Husband testified that in August 2003, Wife took some possessions he received from his deceased parents as well as his personal belongings and threw them out in the driveway. Â 
Vicki Brunson mentored the McGeesâ€™ and the Gregorysâ€™ children.Â  Brunson testified that Husband told her how he would sneak out of the house when Wife was asleep to see Kelly.Â  Brunson further testified that Husband first disclosed to her that he was having a relationship with Kelly in January or February 2003. Â 
In July 2001, Wife began work as a paralegal at Nelson Mullins Riley and Scarborough.Â  Wife earned in excess of $50,000 per year and received excellent performance reviews.Â  Following the separation, Wife experienced emotional problems stemming from the separation.Â  Consequently, Wifeâ€™s performance at work declined, and she was fired in September 2004.Â  Husband and Wife stipulated to a yearly income of $40,000 for Wife.Â  At the time of trial, Wife was drawing unemployment and searching for a job as a paralegal at Columbia law firms.[1]Â  
Husband works for South Carolina Electric and Gas.Â  He is paid an hourly rate of $28.37 and is guaranteed two hundred hours of overtime each year at the rate of $44 per hour.Â  Husband can request more overtime hours but is not guaranteed to receive them.Â  He also testified he earned more overtime in 2004 than he earned in the past due to additional training required for work.Â  His income in recent years was: $34,000 in 1999; $55,000 in 2000; $56,000 in 2001; $62,000 in 2002; and $70,846.24 in 2003.Â  Husband testified that he expected to earn between $70,000 and $75,000 in 2005.Â  
On February 7, 2005, the family court issued an order granting the parties a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  The parties previously entered into a settlement agreement for custody and visitation as well as the division of real and personal property.Â  Under the agreement, Wife received custody of the children, and Husband received reasonable and liberal visitation.Â  
Additionally, Wife received: (1) the marital residence; (2) her 401(k) Retirement Plan; (3) her individual retirement account; and (4) the 1995 Ford Crown Victoria.Â  Husband received: (1) his SCANA stock retirement plan; (2) his 2001 Ford F150 truck; and (3) the joint savings account at the Utilities Employees Credit Union.Â  Further, each party retained ownership of the personal property in his or her possession and any checking, savings, or other accounts in his or her name.Â  Additionally, Husband was to pay Wife $2000 in two equal installments as part of the agreement regarding property division.Â  
The family court found Husband engaged in an open and adulterous affair with a woman who was a friend of the couple, and Husbandâ€™s actions were the primary cause of the breakup of the marriage. Â Further, the family court found Wife lost her job partially due to the grief caused by Husbandâ€™s affair, which led to the breakup of the marriage. Â 
The family court awarded Wife alimony of $250 per month for twenty-four months without specifying the type of alimony awarded.Â  The family court considered factors including: (1) the lifestyle of the parties during the marriage; (2) Wifeâ€™s need for financial assistance, particularly in regards to the residence where the children lived; and (3) the ability of Husband to pay.Â  The family court also ordered Husband to pay child support of $995 per month.Â  The court took several factors into account, including: (1) the fault and demise of the marriage; (2) the relative assets, resources, and income of the parties; (3) the independent assets of Husband; and (4) the results obtained by Wifeâ€™s counsel. Â Ultimately, the family court ordered Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $4000. 
Both Husband and Wife filed Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motions for reconsideration.Â  Husband requested the family court include sufficient findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the alimony award and suggested the family court identify the alimony as lump sum alimony.Â  Husband also argued that the amount of child support awarded was incorrect and should have been $897 per month.Â  Further, Husband argued Wife should not have received attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband argued alternatively, Wife should have received less attorneyâ€™s fees and that the current attorneyâ€™s fees should have been distributed over more than three payments.Â  Husband also requested the order include language indicating that Wife testified she was ultimately responsible for the conduct leading to her loss of employment.Â  Wifeâ€™s arguments in her motion for reconsideration included: (1) the award of alimony should be increased; (2) the divorce decree should specify if the alimony is lump sum or rehabilitative and include grounds to justify the award for twenty-four months; and (3) the time period for payment of alimony should be enlarged.Â  
On August 11, 2005, the family court issued an amended decree of divorce.Â  The amended decree included more detailed findings of fact.Â  Some of those additional findings included: (1) Husband testified that his adultery occurred after the breakup of the marriage and was not the primary cause of the breakup of the marriage; (2) testimony of both parties indicated that communication in the marriage had been strained for a long time; (3) both parties testified their lifestyle included the frequent use of alcohol; (4) Husbandâ€™s witnesses testified as to Wifeâ€™s excessive use of alcohol and her temper and spiteful conduct; and (5) Wife â€œspecifically testified she was ultimately responsible for the conduct which led to the loss of her employment.â€Â  Thereafter the family court revised the child support award to $897 per month.Â  
In regards to alimony, the family court found â€œ[l]ump sum alimony is appropriate based on the special and exceptional circumstances which exist in this case.Â  Specifically, [Wife] was employed with a prestigious law firm earning in excess of $50,000 and lost this employment based in part on her conduct.â€Â  The family court elaborated and found lump sum alimony was appropriate: (1) because Wife requested â€œany form of spousal support or maintenanceâ€; (2) because the award was intended to bridge Wifeâ€™s standard of living following her period of unemployment until her expected return to the work force; (3) to achieve equity based upon the length of the marriage, the relatively young age of the parties, and their respective abilities to earn income and be free of the need of support from the other; and (4) because permanent periodic alimony would undermine the ability for either party to gain closure to this situation, and would serve as a disincentive for Wife to move forward with her life by remarrying or increasing her earning potential, due to Wifeâ€™s desire to punish Husband.Â  The family court modified the alimony to last for thirty-six months in the same monthly amount of $250.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

â€œOn appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When reviewing decisions of the family court, we are cognizant of the fact that it had the opportunity to see the witnesses, hear â€œthe testimony delivered from the stand, and had the benefit of that personal observance of and contact with the parties which is of peculiar value in arriving at a correct result in a case of this character.â€Â  DuBose v. DuBose, 259 S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972); see also Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003) (â€œBecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€). When the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts as well, because it had the benefit of observing the witnesses and determining how much credence to give each witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (holding when evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings).Â  
The amount to be awarded for alimony, as well as a determination of whether the spouse is entitled to alimony, is within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975); see also Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004) (â€œThe amount of alimony is within the [family] courtâ€™s sound discretion and should not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct. App. 2004). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS

Wife argues the family court erred in awarding lump sum alimony rather than permanent periodic or rehabilitative alimony.Â  Additionally, Wife contends the amount of the award was inadequate in light of Husbandâ€™s ability to pay and Wifeâ€™s need for an adequate standard of living.Â  We affirm as modified.
The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as close as is practical, in the same position of support as during the marriage.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). Â If the claim for alimony is well-founded, the family court has the duty of making â€œan alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family court should consider the following factors in awarding alimony: 

  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations; as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant.

Id. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424.Â  
Section 20-3-130(B) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides, 

  Alimony and separate maintenance and support awards may be granted pendente lite and permanently in such amounts and for periods of time subject to conditions as the court considers just including, but not limited to: 
  
    (1) periodic alimony . . . . 
    (2) lump sum alimony . . . .
    (3) rehabilitative alimony . . . .
    (4) reimbursement alimony . . . .
    (5) separate maintenance and support . . . .
    (6) [s]uch other form of spousal support, under terms and conditions as the court may consider just, as appropriate under the circumstances without limitation to grant more than one form of support.Â  
  

The South Carolina Supreme Court has held â€œ[t]hree important factors in awarding periodic alimony are (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the overall financial situation of the parties, especially the ability of the supporting spouse to pay; and (3) whether either spouse was more at fault than the other.â€Â  Patel, 359 S.C. at 529, 599 S.E.2d at 121.Â  
Section 20-3-130(B)(2) describes lump sum alimony as â€œa finite total sum to be paid in one installment, or periodically over a period of time, terminating only upon the death of the supported spouse, but not terminable or modifiable based upon remarriage or changed circumstances in the future.â€ Â The statute further provides the purpose of lump sum alimony may include, but is not limited to, circumstances in which the family court finds alimony appropriate but determines that the award should be finite and nonmodifiable.Â  Id. 
The family court should consider the following factors in determining whether to award lump sum alimony: 

  (1) the financial condition or status of the appellant; (2) the needs of the respondent; (3) the health and ages of both parties; (4) each partyâ€™s earning capacity; (5) the actual income of each party; (6) the individual contributions to the accumulation of their joint wealth; (7) the standard of living by both parties at the time of the divorce; (8) the duration of the marriage; (9) the conduct of the parties; and (10) the special circumstances making any award of lump sum alimony advisable. 


    Atkinson v. Atkinson, 279 S.C. 454, 456-57, 309 S.E.2d 14, 15 (Ct. App. 1983).
Typically, the primary justification for lump sum alimony is the unreliability of the supporting spouse to make regular payments.Â  See Jones v. Jones, 270 S.C. 280, 241 S.E.2d 904 (1978) (upholding the award of $36,000 in lump sum alimony when husband drank excessively, was not regularly employed, had failed to pay child support for the last five years, threatened to leave the country to avoid payments, and had just inherited property valued near $100,000); Murdock v. Murdock,243 S.C. 218, 133 S.E.2d 323 (1963) (affirming lump sum alimony of $4250 when the husband moved to a distant state, remarried, and had been found in contempt of court for failing to pay pendente lite alimony); Hendricks v. Hendricks,285 S.C. 591, 330 S.E.2d 553 (Ct. App. 1985) (affirming lump sum alimony of $30,000 when husband failed to support his family for nineteen years, quickly spent a $45,000 inheritance by purchasing a truck and paying the hospital bills of a paramour in another state); see also Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 217 (3d ed. 2001). 
The circumstances in the present case do not justify lump sum alimony.Â  Husbandâ€™s employment and income is reliable, he currently resides in the area, and he has not failed to make any support payments.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in labeling the award lump sum alimony.
Pursuant to Section 20-3-130(B)(3) rehabilitative alimony is: 

  a finite sum to be paid in one installment or periodically, terminable upon the remarriage or continued cohabitation of the supported spouse, the death of either spouse . . . or the occurrence of a specific event to occur in the future, or modifiable based upon unforeseen events frustrating the good faith efforts of the supported spouse to become self-supporting or the ability of the supporting spouse to pay the rehabilitative alimony.Â  

The purpose of rehabilitative alimony may include, but is not limited to, circumstances when the family court finds providing for the rehabilitation of the supported spouse appropriate.Â  Rehabilitative alimony provides modifiable ending dates coinciding with events considered appropriate by the family court such as the completion of job training or education and the like and requires rehabilitative efforts by the supported spouse.Â  Id.; see also Eagerton v. Eagerton, 285 S.C. 279, 282, 328 S.E.2d 912, 914 (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œThe purpose of rehabilitative alimony is to encourage a dependent spouse to become self-supporting by providing alimony for a limited period of time during which the dependent spouse might retrain and rehabilitate himself or herself thereby limiting the duration of the time in which the supporting spouse is burdened by spousal support.â€). Â Moreover, rehabilitative alimony permits a couple to develop their own lives free from obligations to each other. Â Id. at 282, 328 S.E.2d at 914-15.
The factors to be considered in awarding rehabilitative alimony include: 

  (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the age, health, and education of the supported spouse; (3) the financial resources of the parties; (4) the partiesâ€™ accustomed standard of living; (5) the ability of the supporting spouse to meet his needs while meeting those of the supported spouse; (6) the time necessary for the supported spouse to acquire job training or skills; (7) the likelihood that the supported spouse will successfully complete retraining; and (8) the supported spouseâ€™s likelihood of success in the job market. 

Johnson, at 301-02, 372 S.E.2d at 114.Â  In order for the family court to grant rehabilitative alimony, the evidence must demonstrate the supported spouse will be self-sufficient at the expiration of the ordered payments. Â Toler v. Toler, 292 S.C. 374, 378, 356 S.E.2d 429, 431 (Ct. App. 1987).
While it may be true that Wife needed time to recover from the divorce, she already possesses the necessary skills to be successful in the job market.Â  Thus, the facts of this case do not fit squarely within the parameters of a typical rehabilitative alimony case.Â  
Furthermore, Wifeâ€™s counsel acknowledged at oral argument the facts of this case do not clearly call for permanent periodic alimony.Â  Although lump sum, rehabilitative, and permanent periodic alimony do not fit the facts of this case, we find ample support in the record for alimony under Section 20-3-130(B)(6), which authorizes the award of â€œ[s]uch other form of spousal support, under terms and conditions as the court may consider just, as appropriate under the circumstances.â€
This court may affirm the family court on any ground appearing in the record. See Rule 220(c), SCRAC (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s award of alimony under section 20-3-130(B)(6).Â  See C.A.H. v. L.H., 315 S.C. 389, 434 S.E.2d 268 (1993) (although rehabilitative alimony was not proper under the circumstances, the court found ample support in the record for alimony under Section 20-3-130(B)(6)).Â  This form of alimony is beneficial in the present case because it allows the parties to develop lives separate from each other, which is necessary due to Wifeâ€™s anger towards Husband.Â  While Wife did not need â€œretraining,â€ she needed additional time to reenter the workforce and reach the salary range she attained before losing her job.Â  Although Wife lost her job due to her behavior, that behavior occurred partly as a result of the emotional distress caused when Husband moved out after fifteen years of marriage and subsequently began living with Wifeâ€™s friend.Â  We give the family court discretion in deciding whether to award alimony, and based on the circumstances in this case, the family courtâ€™s decision was not an abuse of discretion.Â  
The family court awarded Wife $250 per month for 36 months.Â  This court recognizes the partiesâ€™ current and reasonably anticipated earnings and expenses as well as the fact that husband has enough disposable income to offset some of the marital debt assigned to Wife in the distribution of marital property.Â  In light of the overall circumstances of this case and Wifeâ€™s monthly expenses coupled with Husbandâ€™s monthly disposable income, we hereby modify Wifeâ€™s alimony award to $500 per month for 36 months.
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] On May 9, 2005, at the hearing on the motion for reconsideration, Husbandâ€™s attorney maintained that Wife had secured a job.Â  The record does not contain any evidence of what the job was or what Wifeâ€™s salary was.Â  At oral argument the parties confirmed that Wife is now working as a paralegal.

 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
Hazel Stoudemire, Appellant.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-150
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 4, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Ben Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In 1995, appellant was sentenced under the Youthful Offender Act (YOA) to an indeterminate term of imprisonment not to exceed six years for grand larceny.Â  At the same time, appellant was also sentenced to concurrent terms of fifteen years imprisonment, suspended upon the service of five years probation, for ten counts of second degree burglary.Â  The probationary period was to commence after appellant served his YOA sentence.Â  Before the probationary period commenced, however, appellant was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder.Â  Because appellantâ€™s commission of the offense of murder prevented him from complying with the conditions of his probation for second degree burglary, the State sought and received a revocation of his probation.Â  
Although appellant does not argue on appeal the precise issue he presented in the trial court, the essence of his position is that he did not â€œwillfullyâ€ violate the conditions of his probation because he was incarcerated for murder.Â  Appellant argues, for example, he did not â€œwillfullyâ€ fail to report in person to the Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, which was a condition of his probation, because his incarceration for murder prevented him from doing so.Â  Appellantâ€™s position, even if preserved, is transparently specious.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. McCray, 332 S.C. 536, 542, 506 S.E.2d 301, 303 (1998) (noting a party cannot argue one ground at trial and another on appeal); State v. Lee, 350 S.C. 125, 130, 564 S.E.2d 372, 375 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œIn the absence of capricious or arbitrary exercise, the discretion of the court in revoking probation will not be disturbed on appeal.â€); and State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 649, 511 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIt is only when probation is revoked solely for failure to pay fines or restitution that a finding of willfulness is mandatory.â€) (emphasis in original).
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Lamar Florida, Inc., successor in interest to Lamar Advertising
          of Mobile, Inc., d/b/a Lamar Advertising of Columbia, Appellant,
        v.
        Li’l Cricket, LLC, Respondent.
      
    
  



Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-151
  Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 4,
  2007 
  Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July 2,
  2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph Gregory Studemeyer, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Edward D. Barnhill, Jr. and Zoe Sanders Nettles, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lamar
  Florida, Inc. appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment against
  Lamarâ€™s claim that Liâ€™l Cricket, L.L.C. trespassed on its real property by
  removing Lamarâ€™s billboard from property leased to Lamar but owned by Liâ€™l
  Cricket.Â  Lamar argues its failure to pay rent did not deprive Lamar of
  exclusive possession of the land and its failure to record the lease did not
  prevent Liâ€™l Cricket from having notice of Lamarâ€™s interest.Â  We affirm.[1]
I.
On
  September 29, 1995, Alvin Miller leased property in Columbia (â€œthe propertyâ€)
  to Outdoor East, predecessor in interest to Lamar, for a period of 5 years for
  $700 per year.Â  The property was the size necessary to support a billboard, and
  the lease was entered for the purpose of construction and maintenance of a
  billboard by Outdoor East.Â  The lease
  agreement does not contain a provision regarding failure to pay rent.Â  As admitted by Lamar, the lease was never
  recorded.Â  
On December 11, 1996, Lamar purchased the billboard and the lease
  interest in the property from Outdoor East.Â  In early 1997, Lamar placed
  nameplates on the billboard.Â  Alvin Miller sold the property to John Miller.Â 
  On November 21, 1997, Liâ€™l Cricket purchased the property from John Miller.Â  
Lamar never paid rent to Liâ€™l Cricket for the property.Â  In a
  letter sent via fax to Lamarâ€™s attorney on or about August 19, 1999, Liâ€™l
  Cricket instructed Lamar to remove the billboard.Â  Liâ€™l Cricket sent another
  letter to Lamar dated August 24, 1999 insisting Lamar remove the billboard by
  August 31, 1999.Â  On or about August 24, 1999, the Jones Sign Company attempted
  to remove the billboard per Liâ€™l Cricketâ€™s request.Â  Lamar prevented the Jones
  Sign Company from fully removing the billboard.Â  In a letter dated August 26, 1999,
  Lamar responded to Liâ€™l Cricketâ€™s action and argued it had a valid lease.Â 
  Lamar attached the lease to the letter.Â  Lamar also sent two letters dated
  September 1, 1999 and September 3, 1999 stating Lamar has a valid lease and Columbia regulations allow Liâ€™l Cricket to erect its own sign without removing Lamarâ€™s
  billboard.Â  
In a letter dated September 3, 1999, Liâ€™l Cricket provided second
  notice to Lamar that the billboard must be removed immediately.Â  On or about
  October 1, 1999, Liâ€™l Cricket wrote the Jones Sign Company instructing them to
  take down the billboard.Â  The Jones Sign Company took down the billboard. 
Lamar brought suit against Liâ€™l Cricket claiming breach of
  contract, conversion, and a violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA).
  Â The trial court granted summary judgment on the claims for conversion and a
  violation of UTPA, which was affirmed by this court and Lamarâ€™s petition for
  certiorari was denied on September 9, 2004.[2]Â Â  
Lamar moved to amend its complaint to include claims against Liâ€™l
  Cricket for trespass to real property and trespass to personal property.Â  The
  trial court first denied Lamarâ€™s motion, but the trial court later granted
  Lamarâ€™s motion to alter or amend, thereby allowing Lamar to amend its complaint
  to include claims for trespass to real and personal property.Â  Subsequently,
  the trial court granted Liâ€™l Cricketâ€™s motion for summary judgment regarding
  Lamarâ€™s claim for trespass to real property.Â  This appeal followed.
II.
â€œAn
  appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard
  applied by the trial court.â€Â  Houck v. State Farm
    Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is only appropriate when clearly no
  genuine issue of material fact exists and the moving party is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law. Â Rule 56(c),
  SCRCP; Cafe Assocs., Ltd. v. Gerngross, 305 S.C. 6, 9, 406 S.E.2d 162,
  164 (1991).Â  However, summary judgment is not
  appropriate if further inquiry into the caseâ€™s facts is desirable for the
  application of the law.Â  Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 378, 534
    S.E.2d 688, 692 (2000).Â  Conversely, â€œwhen plain, palpable, and
  indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary
  judgment should be granted.â€Â  Hedgepath v.
    Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 355, 559 S.E.2d
  327, 336 (Ct. App. 2001).
III.
A. Trespass
Lamar
  argues the trial court erred by granting summary judgment to Liâ€™l Cricket on
  Lamarâ€™s claim for trespass to real property after the trial court found Lamarâ€™s
  claim lacked two key elements: Liâ€™l Cricketâ€™s intentional invasion and Lamarâ€™s
  exclusive possession.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[T]respass
  is any intentional invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s interest in the exclusive
  possession of his property . . . .â€Â  Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358
  S.C. 280, 296, 594 S.E.2d 557, 565 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Hedgepath v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 356, 559 S.E.2d 327, 337 (Ct. App.
  2001)).Â  The trial court held summary judgment for
  trespass to real property was appropriate because the unrecorded lease provided
  no notice preventing Liâ€™l Cricket from intentionally invading the property and
  Lamarâ€™s failure to pay rent prohibited Lamar from having exclusive possession
  of the property.Â  
1.     Â Intentional Invasion
Lamar
  contends the trial court erred by holding Liâ€™l Cricket did not intentionally
  invade Lamarâ€™s interest because Liâ€™l Cricket lacked notice of the lease
  agreement between Outdoor East and Miller, Lamar and Liâ€™l Cricketâ€™s
  predecessors of title.Â  We disagree. 
Section
  30-7-10 of the South Carolina Code (2007) requires leases for more than twelve
  months to be recorded in order to affect the rights of subsequent purchasers
  without notice.Â  Additionally, section 30-7-90 of the South Carolina Code
  (2007) provides:

  No
    possession of real property described in any instrument of writing required by
    law to be recorded shall operate as notice of such instrument. Actual notice
    shall be deemed and held sufficient to supply the place of registration only
    when such notice is of the instrument itself or of its nature and purport.

The lease,
  originally between Outdoor East and Miller, was for five years.Â  Lamar admits
  the lease was never recorded.Â  Further, possession of the property and Lamarâ€™s
  use of name plates on the billboard did not qualify as actual notice under
  section 30-7-90.Â  Thus, Liâ€™l Cricket did not have notice of Lamarâ€™s interest
  and accordingly, Liâ€™l Cricket could not intentionally invade Lamarâ€™s interest.Â  
2. Exclusive Possession
Lamar
  argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Liâ€™l Cricket for
  Lamarâ€™s claim of trespass to real property because Lamar lacked exclusive
  possession of the property.Â  We disagree.
Exclusive
  possession is defined as â€œthe exercise of exclusive dominion over property,
  including the use and benefit of the property.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1184 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Section 27-35-140 of the South Carolina Code (2007)
  states, â€œ[f]ailure to pay the rent agreed upon when due, or a reasonable
  rent for use and occupation when demanded, shall terminate all tenancies for a
  term, for years, from month to month and at will and the tenant shall forthwith
  vacate the premises without notice.â€Â  We know of no reason, and Appellant cites
  none, why this statutory provision does not control the disposition of this
  case, particularly because the lease is silent on the consequences of a failure
  to pay rent. 
Appellant
  points to Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C.
  271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994), and Litchfield Co. of South Carolina, Inc. v.
    Kiriakides, 290 S.C. 220, 349 S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1986), to argue failure
  to pay rent does not automatically result in the termination of a lease.Â  However, Kiriakides prevents forfeiture by landlords for trivial breaches.Â  312
  S.C. at 275-76, 349 S.E.2d at 366.Â  This case is easily distinguishable because
  the complete failure to pay rent under the circumstances presented is not a
  trivial breach. Â Litchfield is also distinguishable.Â  In Litchfield,
  the method of terminating the tenancy was clearly set forth by the lease.Â  290
  S.C. at 225-26, 349 S.E.2d at 347-48.Â  In the case before us, as previously
  noted, the lease does not contain a provision regarding the failure to pay
  rent.
The lease agreement requires payment of $700 annually.Â  Lamar
  admitted it did not make any rental payments to Liâ€™l Cricket.Â  Liâ€™l Cricket
  purchased the property on November 21, 1997.Â  The billboard was taken down
  around October 1, 1999.Â  Lamar argues only one rent payment was missed over the
  time period.Â  The evidence provided at trial, however, shows Liâ€™l Cricket owned
  the property for almost two years without receiving any payment from Lamar.Â 
  Therefore, Lamarâ€™s breach of the lease agreement was material as a matter of
  law, and it surrendered its exclusive possession of the property.Â  Accordingly,
  Liâ€™l Cricket did not trespass on Lamarâ€™s real property because Lamar did not
  have exclusive possession of the property.
B. Prior Opinion by Court of
  Appeals
Lamar
  argues the trial court erred in relying on an unpublished opinion of this court
  related to additional causes of action brought by Lamar against Liâ€™l Cricket
  arising from the same facts.Â  While there may be merit to this argument, we
  find that any error was harmless because the trial courtâ€™s reliance on these
  statements was inconsequential. 
â€œAn
  error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal.â€Â  Brown
    v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997).Â 
  â€œAn error is not reversible unless it is material and prejudicial to the
  substantial rights of the appellant.â€Â  Visual Graphics Leasing Corp., Inc.
    v. Lucia, 311 S.C. 484, 489, 429 S.E.2d 839, 841 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
In
  its order, the trial court stated:

  The
    record reflects that Liâ€™l Cricket had neither actual notice of the instrument
    itself nor of its nature and purport.Â  The Court of Appealâ€™s decision affirming
    summary judgment as to conversion provided: â€œ[W]hen Liâ€™l Cricket purchased the
    property, it lacked knowledge of the lease between Lamar and Al Miller.Â  At no
    time did Liâ€™l Cricket receive rent for the sign.Â  Lamar Adver. of Mobile,
      Inc. d/b/a Lamar Adver. of Columbia v. Liâ€™l Cricket LLC, Ct. App. Op.
    2003-UP-483.Â  The Court of Appeals further stated [t]he lease was never
    recorded.â€Â  Id.Â  Additionally, the deposition testimony of Al Miller,
    the owner of the property from whom Liâ€™l Cricket purchased the property and the
    person with whom Lamar had the alleged lease, shows Liâ€™l Cricket had no notice
    of the lease when it purchased the property.

Though the trial
  court did reference this courtâ€™s prior unpublished opinion, the record
  otherwise provides an ample basis to support the finding that Liâ€™l Cricket
  lacked knowledge of the lease between Lamar and Al Miller.Â  Thus, any error was
  harmless error.
IV.
The
  entry of summary judgment in favor of Liâ€™l Cricket is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] See Lamar Adver. v. Liâ€™l Cricket, LLC, Op. No. 2003-UP-483 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Aug. 20, 2003).Â
