title: State v. Hernandez
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Raphael Hernandez, Honorio Guerrero, and Alfredo Avila-Arjona, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Edgefield County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-183
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 18, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellants.Â 
			
			Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Sabrina C. Todd, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Raphael Hernandez, Honorio Guerrero, and Alfredo Avila-Arjona (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the trial courtâ€™s denial of their motions for directed verdicts.Â  Appellants claim the State failed to produce any evidence showing Appellants knowingly attempted to possess the marijuana at issue.Â  Further, Appellants contend the State showed only that they were present at the scene, and their presence without the requisite knowledge warrants a reversal of the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  We affirm.Â 
 
FACTS
On May 14, 2002, United States customs agents discovered marijuana concealed inside furniture on a semi-trailer as it crossed into the United States from Mexico. Â Once the drugs were detected at the border, United States Customs and Border Protection contacted a customs agent in Greenville, South Carolina to arrange an undercover transfer of the drugs.Â  The furniture in which the drugs were hidden was scheduled to be delivered to Fredy DeLeon, owner of Tienda DeLeon, in Trenton, South Carolina.Â  Four days later, local, state, and federal authorities participated in a controlled delivery of approximately nine-hundred pounds of marijuana.Â 
 
Once the delivery arrived at Tienda DeLeon, an undercover customs agent and two other men from the store unloaded a portion of the semi-trailerâ€™s cargo.Â  However, the majority of the cargo remained inside the semi-trailer.Â  DeLeon instructed the driver and the undercover agent to transport the remaining cargo to Billyâ€™s Super Store and to wait there until some gentlemen arrived.Â  When the driver and the customs agent arrived at Billyâ€™s Super Store, the undercover agent backed the semi-trailer up to a loading bay.Â  No one was present when the semi-trailer arrived.
 
After approximately twenty-five or thirty minutes, a green Thunderbird, which was previously parked at Tienda DeLeon, drove past the semi-trailer.Â  The Thunderbird reappeared a few minutes later and pulled into the parking lot, immediately followed by a moving truck.Â  Appellant Guerrero drove the moving truck, and Appellants Hernandez and Avila-Arjona were passengers.Â  The moving truck stopped perpendicular to the front of the semi-trailer, and the Thunderbird pulled along the driverâ€™s side of the semi-trailer, making it impossible for the semi-trailer to leave.Â  The Thunderbirdâ€™s passenger approached the driverâ€™s side and attempted to get inside the semi-trailer. Â However, the undercover agent refused to allow him inside the semi-trailer.Â 
 
Meanwhile, the Thunderbirdâ€™s driver proceeded to talk with Appellants who were inside the moving truck.Â  According to the customs agent, at least one of the two men in the Thunderbird was initially present at Tienda DeLeon.Â  The Thunderbirdâ€™s passenger then instructed the driver and the customs agent to follow the moving truck and the Thunderbird.Â  The three vehicles drove for an extended period of time on unpaved rural roads, and eventually, the moving truck and the semi-trailer became stuck in mud.Â  The authorities then decided to end the undercover operation.Â 
 
While the Thunderbird managed to escape, Appellants and DeLeon were arrested at the scene.Â  A search of the semi-trailer revealed substantial amounts of marijuana.Â  However, the cargo portion of the moving truck was completely empty.Â  The authorities discovered rental paperwork inside the moving truck that showed Appellant Guerrero had rented the moving truck on May 17, 2002.
On March 22, 2004, an Edgefield grand jury indicted Appellants and DeLeon for trafficking approximately nine-hundred pounds of marijuana.Â  A trial was held June 28 through July 6, 2004. Â At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, counsel for Appellants moved for directed verdicts, claiming the State had proved no more than Appellantsâ€™ mere presence at the scene and had failed to prove knowledge, a required element to convict a person for trafficking in marijuana. Â 
The trial court denied Appellantsâ€™ motions for directed verdicts. Â Appellants later renewed these motions at the conclusion of DeLeonâ€™s case, which the trial court again denied.Â  A jury found Appellants guilty of trafficking in marijuana, and the trial court sentenced Appellants to twenty-five years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, this Court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State. Â State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 633, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004). Â When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 477-78 (2004).
If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury. Â State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged. Â State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003).Â  Similarly, the trial court should grant a directed verdict when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty. Â State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 102, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005). 

LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the State presented evidence that they were present when the marijuana was seized, but it failed to establish they knowingly attempted to possess the marijuana at issue.Â  Consequently, Appellants contend the trial court erred in failing to direct verdicts of not guilty for trafficking in marijuana.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
Section 44-53-370 of the South Carolina Code (1976 & Supp. 2006) defines trafficking in marijuana as:Â  
 

	(e) Any person who knowingly sells, manufactures, cultivates, delivers, purchases, or brings into this State, or who provides financial assistance or otherwise aids, abets, attempts, or conspires to sell, manufacture, cultivate, deliver, purchase, or bring into this State, or who is knowingly in actual or constructive possession 
	or who knowingly attempts to become in actual or constructive possession of:
	(1) ten pounds or more of marijuana is guilty of a felony which is known as 
	â€œtrafficking in marijuanaâ€ and, upon conviction, must be punished as follows if the quantity involved is:
	Â . . . (b) one hundred pounds or more, but less than two thousand pounds, or one hundred to one thousand marijuana plants regardless of weight, a mandatory term of imprisonment of twenty-five years, no part of which may be suspended nor probation granted, and a fine of twenty-five thousand dollars . . . .

(emphasis added).Â   
In drug cases, our Supreme Court has recognized that the element of knowledge is seldom susceptible of direct proof, so it may be proven by circumstantial evidence. Â See State v. Attardo, 263 S.C. 546, 550, 211 S.E.2d 868, 869 (1975) (holding that in prosecution for knowing or intentional possession of controlled substances, knowledge can be proven by evidence of acts, declarations, or conduct of the accused from which the inference may be drawn that the accused knew of the existence of the prohibited substance). Knowledge is generally a question for the jury. Â Id.
The Appellantsâ€™ behavior and actions while at Billyâ€™s Super Store were markedly suspicious, and the ensuing course of events was inconsistent with what a reasonable delivery of furniture would entail. Â First, the Thunderbird drove past the semi-trailer and then out of the customs agentâ€™s sight before stopping at Billyâ€™s Super Store, apparently to ensure that it was safe to proceed with the delivery.Â  The Thunderbird returned with the moving truck only after first driving past the undercover agent.Â  The agent testified that the moving truck and the Thunderbird proceeded to block the semi-trailer, which precluded the semi-trailer from moving in any direction.Â  The Thunderbirdâ€™s driver then conversed with Appellants while the Thunderbirdâ€™s passenger instructed the undercover agents to follow them to a rural area where Appellants would unload the semi-trailer. Â Although all parties were at Billyâ€™s Super Store where it was clearly more practical to unload the furniture, Appellants still attempted to move the furniture to a more rural and less visible location.Â  These actions were inconsistent with transporting furniture as the moving truck was completely empty and contained sufficient room to transport the furniture from Billyâ€™s Super Store to its final destination.Â 
 
All of these actions, while not direct proof of a knowing attempt to possess marijuana, formed substantial circumstantial evidence to send the case to the jury, as Appellantsâ€™ actions and behavior were inconsistent with the seemingly innocuous task of unloading furniture.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in refusing to direct verdicts in Appellantsâ€™ favor.
CONCLUSION
Although we recognize the State presented minimal, if any, direct evidence at trial to show Appellants knew the semi-trailer contained marijuana, we find Appellantsâ€™ actions and behavior during the undercover operation constituted substantial circumstantial evidence so as to require the caseâ€™s submission to the jury.Â  For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Salters v. Palmetto Health Alliance
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Peggy Salters, Respondent,
				v.
				Palmetto Health Alliance Inc; d/b/a Palmetto Baptist Medical Centers; Robert Schnackenberg, M.D., individually; Eric Lewkowiez, M.D., individually; Columbia Psychiatric Associates, PA, P. Kenneth Huggins, M.D., individually, Defendants,
				of whom Eric Lewkowiez, M.D. 
				Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-187
Submitted April 3, 2007 â€“ Filed April 24, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William H. Davidson, II, Andrew F. Lindemann,
				Lawrence S. Kerr, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John W. Carrigg, Jr., Mark Weston Hardee, Peter Demos Protopapas, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this medical malpractice action, Dr. Eric Lewkowiez appeals the trial courtâ€™s refusal to direct a verdict or a judgment notwithstanding the verdict in his favor.Â  Dr. Lewkowiez contends the evidence presented at trial was insufficient to prove to a reasonable degree of medical certainty that his alleged breach of the standard of care proximately caused Peggy Saltersâ€™ injuries.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This appeal concerns a series of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) treatments Salters received as a result of severe depression. Â Salters first received ECT treatments in the late 1980â€™s when medication did not seem to alleviate her depression.Â  Her physician at the time, Dr. John Emerick, recommended ECT treatments.Â  Dr. Emerick noted as the ECT treatments progressed Salters became less depressed, more organized, and less suicidal.Â  Â Â Â Â Â She again underwent treatments in 1990, and the ECT appeared to lessen her symptoms.Â  From 1992-99 Salters had no psychiatric history.
 
In 1998, Salters received a Masters of Science in Nursing and, in 1999, became certified as a nurse practioner.Â  During this time, Salters experienced the deaths of several close family members, most notably, the death of her husband in October 1999.Â  These deaths had a severe effect on Saltersâ€™ mental health and she again sought psychiatric care. Â Â 
On August 8, 2000, she met with Dr. Lewkowiez. Â At their first meeting, he found Salters was tearful, had low energy, and had trouble sleeping.Â  Salters informed him she had a poor appetite, and in fact, had lost forty pounds since her husbandâ€™s death.Â  Dr. Lewkowiez diagnosed Salters with major depression, recurrent and severe.Â  He also believed she suffered from passive suicidal ideation, which is a condition describing people who have suicidal thoughts but no plans to implement suicide.Â  Dr. Lewkowiez recommended numerous anti-depressant drugs as part of Saltersâ€™ treatment.Â  Â Â 
Between September 13 and Saltersâ€™ next appointment with Dr. Lewkowiez on October 2, Salters called Dr. Lewkowiez from Salt Lake City, Utah and informed him it was her intention to commit suicide, however, after they spoke, Salters changed her mind.Â  The antidepressants appeared to have no effect on Salters and she was unable to function at work.Â  Therefore, when she next saw Dr. Lewkowiez, he broached the subject of ECT because the procedure had been effective in the past.Â  This was the first time Dr. Lewkowiez had ever recommended a patient for ECT and he referred Salters to Dr. Robert Schnackenberg. Â Â Dr. Lewkowiez spoke to Dr. Schnackenberg and they examined her past medical records â€œextensively,â€ including her history of ECT.Â  Both doctors felt she was an appropriate candidate for the procedure.
Dr. Schnackenberg administered ECT on October 9, 11, 13, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 23, 24, 25, 26, and 27, 2000, and on November 3, 10, and 17, 2000.Â  Â The first set of treatments were spaced conventionally, and given every other day.Â  The following two weeks Dr. Schnackenberg administered what are referred to in the medical community as intensive or regressive ECTsâ€”which are ECTs administered daily.Â  The ECT treatments Dr. Schnackenberg administered in November were considered maintenance ECT which continued the effects of the previously administered ECTs.
On October 10, 2000, on Saltersâ€™ outpatient ECT record, a notation made by one of the nurses provided: â€œfaxed to Dr. Lewkowiez 10/11/00 at 1:10 p.m.â€Â  Ten days later on October 20, a notation on the outpatient record provided: â€œOffice Rosa notified at 3:35 she states Dr. Lewkowiez called and he will check on patient today.â€Â  Although both of these medical records seem to suggest Dr. Lewkowiez had contact with Salters, he denied having any contact with her until November, after the intensive ECTs had already been administered.
On November 2, Dr. Lewkowiez met with Salters.Â  His notes from their meeting show that Salters missed an ECT the previous Monday and that she had memory difficulties.Â  However, Dr. Lewkoweiz did not recommend she stop the ECT and, in fact, Dr. Schnackenbergâ€™s records suggest he encouraged her to continue with the ECT.Â  Moreover, he did not inform Dr. Schnackenberg about Salters memory complaints. Â Â On November 13, they met again and Dr. Lewkowiez noted Salters had â€œcontinued difficultyâ€ with her memory and that she was unable to function at work or home.Â  Additionally, Salters was losing weight and unable to sleep.Â  On November 30, Dr. Lewkowiez observed Salters continued â€œto be confused and disoriented.â€Â  At this point, Salters decided to stop the ECT because she was â€œcompletely unable to function.â€Â  Â 
After Salters stopped the ECT treatments, her memory problems did not subside.Â Â  She continued to see Dr. Lewkowiez and he recommended she go on disability.Â  He did not believe she had the ability to pay attention, listen and do what was necessary to treat patients.Â  Eventually, Dr. Lewkowiez recommended Salters see psychologist Dr. Mary Elizabeth Shea for memory loss secondary to ECT. Â In Dr. Sheaâ€™s opinion, Salters suffered memory loss as a result of the ECT treatments.
Salters filed suit against Dr. Lewkowiez, Dr. Schnackenberg, Dr. Huggins, as well as Columbia Psychiatric Associates, P.A.,[2] and Palmetto Baptist Hospital,[3] alleging the physicians were liable for memory loss she sustained following a course of negligent treatment for severe depression that included ECT.Â  At trial, Salters offered expert testimony to establish the negligence of these physicians proximately caused her memory loss.Â  At the close of the evidence, the physicians moved for a directed verdict.Â  Dr. Lewkowiez argued he did not breach the standard of care, moreover, any alleged breach did not proximately cause Saltersâ€™ injuries.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  After trial, the jury found in favor of Dr. Huggins and Dr. Schnackenberg and found in favor of Salters against Dr. Lewkowiez for medical negligence in the amount of $625,177.00 in actual damages.Â  After the verdict, Dr. Lewkowiez filed a motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict or judgment notwithstanding the verdict, the trial court must â€œview the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.â€ Sabb v. S.C. State University  350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  â€œIf the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.â€Â  Martasin v. Hilton Head Health Sys., 364 S.C. 430, 437, 613 S.E.2d 795, 799 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Lewkowiez argues the trial court erred in not granting a directed verdict or a judgment notwithstanding the verdict because Salters failed to present sufficient evidence to establish the requisite causal connection between Lewkoweizâ€™s alleged breach of the standard of care and Saltersâ€™ injury.Â  Specifically, Lewkowiez argues his alleged breach of the standard of care could not be the proximate cause of Saltersâ€™ injuries because her expert testified the intensive ECT caused Saltersâ€™ disabilities and Dr. Lewkoweiz did not meet with her until after that part of the treatment was over.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, a physician commits malpractice by failing to exercise the requisite degree of skill and learning generally possessed and exercised by other members of the medical profession acting in a similar situation or circumstance.Â  David v. McLeod Regional Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  A plaintiff in a medical malpractice action must first establish by expert testimony, unless the subject matter is of such common knowledge that no special testimony is needed, â€œevidence of the generally recognized practice and procedures that would be exercised by competent practitioners in a defendant doctorâ€™s field of medicine under the same or similar circumstances. Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 254, 487 S.E.2d 596, 599 (1997) (citation omitted).Â  Secondly, the plaintiff must show the defendant physicianâ€™s departure from the generally accepted medical standards and procedures.Â  Id. 
 
Further, â€œit is incumbent on the plaintiff to establish proximate cause as well as the negligence of the physician.â€Â  Ellis v. Oliver, 323 S.C. 121, 125, 473 S.E.2d 793, 796 (1996) (citation omitted).Â  As the South Carolina Supreme Court noted in Ellis, â€œnegligence may be deemed a proximate cause only when without such negligence the injury would not have occurred or could have been avoided.â€Â  323 S.C. at 125, 473 S.E.2d at 795.Â  A party relying solely on expert testimony to establish proximate cause between the physicianâ€™s negligence and the plaintiffâ€™s injury, must introduce evidence the physicianâ€™s negligence â€œmost probably resulted in the injuries alleged.â€Â  Gooding, 326 S.C. at 254, 487 S.E.2d at 599.Â  â€œHowever, in determining whether particular evidence meets the â€˜most probablyâ€™ test, it is not necessary the testifying expert actually use the words â€˜most probably.â€™â€Â  Martasin v. Hilton Head Health Sys., 364 S.C. 430, 438, 613 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted).Â  As long as the expertâ€™s testimony is such â€œas to judicially impress that the opinion . . . represents his professional judgment as to the most likely one among the possible causesâ€ the testimony will be deemed sufficient to establish proximate cause.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel., 306 S.C. 101, 111, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991) (citation omitted). 
 
In this case, Saltersâ€™ presented the testimony of Dr. Peter Breggin, a psychiatrist and an expert in ECT to establish the standard of care for attending psychiatrists who continue to care for their patients after referring the patient to a specialist.Â  Dr. Breggin testified as to the duties of attending and treating physicians for when patients develop severe cognitive side effects.Â  Â Dr. Breggin testified Dr. Lewkowiez and Dr. Schnackenberg had a duty to â€œreview and adjust the treatment technique being used, (e.g., switching to unilateral ECT, lowering the electric dose administered, and/or increasing the time interval between the treatments).â€Â  

Dr. Breggin opined in this particular case that the standard of care required Dr. Lewkowiez to communicate to Dr. Schnackenberg the side effects the ECT treatments were having on Salters.Â  According to Dr. Breggin, Dr. Lewkoweizâ€™s medical records indicated Salters was experiencing memory problems and that her personality had drastically changed.Â  However, Dr. Lewkowiez did not inform Dr. Schnackenberg of these changes; rather, Dr. Schnackenbergâ€™s medical records show Dr. Lewkowiez encouraged Salters to continue with the treatments.Â  Based on his review of the medical records, Dr. Breggin concluded Dr. Lewkowiez deviated from the standard of care by not stopping the ECT treatments after he saw Saltersâ€™ change in personality.Â  Â Further, Dr. Breggin stated he believed Saltersâ€™ disability was caused by the intensive ECT treatments.Â  He elucidated:

	Itâ€™s cumulative.Â  We see her having some memory loss and cognitive problems from the first ECTs; and then from the later ECTs. But she keeps recovering and going back to work and functioning on a high level; and finally sheâ€™s tipped over by the accumulation and the intensive ECT.
	

Even if the only evidence of causation was Dr. Bregginâ€™s testimony, when viewed in a light most favorable to Salters, a jury could have inferred the cumulative effect of the intensive and maintenance ECT treatments were the proximate cause of her injuries, and had Dr. Lewkowiez informed Dr. Schnackenburg of the changes Salters was experiencing, the treatments would have stopped.Â 
 
Dr. Lewkowiez maintains that because he did not see Salters until after Dr. Schnackenberg had administered the intensive ECTs, when the damage to Salters had already occurred, his alleged breach of the standard of care described by Dr. Breggin could not be the proximate cause of the injuries.Â  First, as noted above, there is evidence in the record from which the jury could have inferred the cumulative effect of the ECT treatments caused Saltersâ€™ injuries.Â  Secondly, assuming only the intensive ECT did cause Saltersâ€™ injuries a reasonable jury could have found the medical records dated October 10 and 20 show that Dr. Lewkoweiz did check to see how Salters was tolerating the ECT.
 
Dr. Lewkoweiz points to the South Carolina Supreme Courtâ€™s recent decision in David v. McLeod Regional Medical Center, to support his proposition that Salters failed to establish how the facts of the case would have been different had Dr. Lewkoweiz informed Dr. Schnackenberg that Saltersâ€™ personality had drastically changed and she was suffering from severe memory loss. In David, unlike the situation presented here, the supreme court found the appellant provided no evidence how his injuries would have been different had the physician communicated his thoughts for treatment to the pathologist:Â  
 

	Stated differently, Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit fails to explain how Dr. Brussettâ€™s post-diagnosis treatment would have affected the pathologistâ€™s initial diagnosis of the tumor.Â  As a result, there is no evidence that Dr. Brussettâ€™s failure to communicate Appellants possible treatment options with the pathologist was the proximate cause of Appellantsâ€™ injuries.

367 S.C. at 249, 626 S.E.2d at 4. Â We also note in David the appellant failed to provide the standard of care the physicians allegedly breached.Â  Id.Â  In this case, not only did Dr. Breggin testify regarding the standard of care, his testimony provided the jury with evidence on the effect Dr. Lewkowiez breach had upon Salters.Â  Dr. Breggin testified that Dr. Lewkowiez â€œdid nothing to stop the ECT . . . thereâ€™s the report of the memory problems and the change is fairly obvious and he did nothing to interfere at that point.â€Â Â  Further, Dr. Breggin testified Dr. Lewkowiez should have called Dr. Schnackenberg and informed him of Saltersâ€™ reaction to the procedure.Â  We find there is ample evidence that as a result of Dr. Lewkowiezâ€™s failure to inform Dr. Schnackenberg of Satlersâ€™ reaction to the procedure, she was exposed to additional ECT treatments.Â  Viewing the totality of the evidence, we conclude a jury could have found Salersâ€™ injuries were most probably the result of Dr. Lewkowiezâ€™s breach of the standard of care.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in failing to grant a directed verdict or a judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
 
Next, Dr. Lewkowiez argues the trial court erred in finding he had a duty to monitor Saltersâ€™ progress because the issue was not presented at trial nor mentioned in the complaint.Â  Although the words â€œduty to monitorâ€ may not have been uttered during the course of the trial, when reviewing Dr. Bregginâ€™s testimony it is clear the duty to communicate is essentially the duty to monitor.Â  Further, because of the disposition of the first issue, there is no need to address this argument.
Dr. Lewkowiez also contends the trial court erred by finding him liable under a vicarious liability theory.Â  The trial court did not charge the jury regarding vicarious liability nor is there any evidence in the record that such a theory was presented at trial.Â  Accordingly, this argument has no merit. 
 
CONCLUSION
We find sufficient evidence upon which a jury could conclude Dr. Lewkowiezâ€™s breach of the standard of care proximately caused Saltersâ€™ injuries.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Salters alleges Lewkowiez and Schnackenberg are members of Columbia Psychiatric Associates but the record is unclear on this point.
[3] During the course of the trial, Salters settled with Palmetto Baptist Hospital.

title: Poston v. Brown
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR. 
 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				David Poston and Renee Poston, individually and as husband and wife, Appellants,
				v.
				Tod Brown, M. D., individually; Carolinas Hospital System; Carolinas Hospital System Pharmacy; John Doe I, an unknown Corporation and/or Professional Association, Defendants,
				of whom Tod Brown, M. D. is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-188
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 24, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED 



	
		
			
				Henry Thad White, Jr., of Florence, for Appellants.
				J. Boone Aiken, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Â  David and Renee Poston brought suit against Dr. Tod Brown alleging medical malpractice.Â  The Postons appeal from the trial judgesâ€™ orders, alleging (1) the judge erred in admitting the testimony of Nurse Patrick Taylor and (2) the judge erred in excluding two expert witnesses from testifying at trial.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Menne v. Keowee Key Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc., 368 S.C. 557, 568, 629 S.E.2d 690, 696 (Ct. App. 2006) (finding the admissibility of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and, on appeal, will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error prejudicing the defendant); Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (â€œTo warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., that there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack thereof.â€).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: McMasters v. Charpia
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				RenÃ© McMasters, Respondent,
				v.
				Jody E. Charpia, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-189
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 24, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Frederick James Newton, of Summerville, for Appellant.
				Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â RenÃ© McMasters brought this action against Jody E. Charpia to set aside a deed of property to Charpia from Charpiaâ€™s husband, Howard, on the basis it was a fraudulent conveyance.Â  The conveyance was made at a time when McMasters had litigation pending against Charpiaâ€™s husband.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment to McMasters, finding the deed should be set aside pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth, codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-23-10(A) (2007).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In June 2002, McMasters sued Charpiaâ€™s husband, seeking money damages for alleged construction defects in a new home located in North Charleston, South Carolina.[2]Â  Charpiaâ€™s husband was the builder.[3]Â   
By deed dated November 5, 2003, Charpiaâ€™s husband transferred title to the partiesâ€™ marital residence to Charpia.Â  The deed was recorded in the Office of the Register of Mesne Conveyances for Dorchester County on December 30, 2003.Â  According to the deed, the transfer was â€œin consideration of the sum of ONE and no/100 DOLLAR ($1.00), this being a deed of gift and the full consideration paid by my wife Jody E. Charpia, the Grantee, on the delivery of this deed . . . .â€Â  At the time of this transfer, McMasterâ€™s lawsuit against Charpiaâ€™s husband for alleged construction defects was still pending.Â  Â Â 
In August 2004, McMasters obtained a judgment of $191,600.00 against Charpiaâ€™s husband in the Court of Common Pleas for Dorchester County on her original action for alleged construction deficiencies.[4]Â  McMasters filed an action for fraudulent conveyance against Charpia in September 2004.Â  McMasters asked that the conveyance of property to Charpia be set aside based on the Statute of Elizabeth, which provides that transfers of property to creditors or others to avoid a suit or debt shall be deemed void.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-23-10(A) (2007).
In November 2005, McMasters filed a motion requesting summary judgment.Â  She asserted no genuine issues of material fact were in dispute in this action and she was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Â Â 
After a hearing, the circuit court granted the motion for summary judgment and set aside the conveyance pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth.Â  The court stated McMasters would be allowed to seek levy and execution upon the residence in satisfaction, or partial satisfaction, of the judgment she had obtained.Â  Â Â 
In setting aside the conveyance, the circuit court found the residence transferred to Charpia was worth somewhere between $140,000.00 and $150,000.00, was not encumbered by a mortgage, â€œwas clearly a gift,â€ and â€œwas conveyed at a time when Charpiaâ€™s husband was aware of the claim being asserted by McMasters.â€Â  Although the court found there was no actual intent to defraud, it concluded no actual intent was required since the conveyance was not supported by valuable consideration.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Charpia contends the circuit court erred (1) in determining the conveyance of property from her husband should be set aside pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth because this provision is inapplicable; and, (2) even assuming the statute applies, the court erred in finding that the conveyance was not supported by valuable consideration.

	The Statute of Elizabeth provides in relevant part as follows:
	
		(A)Â  Every gift, grant, alienation, bargain, 
		transfer, and conveyance of lands, . . . goods and chattels or any of them, . . . which may be had or made . . . for any intent or purpose to delay, hinder, or defraud 
		creditors and others of their just and lawful actions, suits, debts, accounts, damages, penalties, and forfeitures must be deemed and taken (only as against that person or persons, his or their heirs, successors, executors, administrators and assigns . . . ) to be clearly and utterly void . . . and of no effect, . . . any other matter or thing to the contrary notwithstanding.
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-23-10(A) (2007) (emphasis added).
Charpia first â€œasserts that the Statute [of Elizabeth] is inapplicable to the transfer because [McMasters] was not a creditor of Howard W. Charpia at the time of the transfer of the property.â€Â  Specifically, she argues that when the transfer of property occurred in 2003, McMasters had not yet obtained a judgment against her husband; therefore, McMasters was, â€œ[a]t best, . . . a potential future creditor at the time of the transferâ€ because her husband owed no debt to McMasters.Â 
 
We find no merit to this assertion.Â  The statute itself expressly provides that it applies to the transfer of property â€œfor any intent or purpose to delay, hinder, or defraud creditors and others of their just and lawful actions, suits, debts, accounts, [and] damages . . . .â€Â  Id. Â§ 27-23-10(A) (emphasis added).
Our supreme court has specifically held, based on the statuteâ€™s express language, the Statute of Elizabeth â€œdoes not limit its application to judgment creditors.Â  Rather, its protection extends to other types of partiesâ€ affected by the conveyance of the property.Â  Lebovitz v. Mudd, 293 S.C. 49, 52, 358 S.E.2d 698, 700 (1987).Â Â  Â Â 
Charpia next contends that, even if the statute is applicable, the â€œcourt erred in finding that the conveyance to [her] was not supported by valuable consideration.â€Â  She asserts she actually paid her husband the sum of one dollar that was recited in the deed.Â  Further, she asserts small sums or deeds citing â€œlove and affectionâ€ provide sufficient consideration under our case law, and even though the deed did not state the consideration was for â€œlove and affection, it is implicit in the familial relationship between [Charpia and her husband] by virtue of the bonds of holy matrimony.â€Â 
 
Our supreme court has held no actual intent to defraud need be shown when a transfer is not supported by valuable consideration:

	We have held that under [the Statute of Elizabeth], conveyances shall be set aside under two conditions:Â  First, where the transfer is made by the grantor with the actual intent of defrauding his creditors where that intent is imputable to the grantee, even though there is a valuable consideration; and, second, where a transfer is made without actual intent to defraud the grantorâ€™s creditors, but without consideration.Â  . . .Â Â  If the transfer was not made on a valuable consideration, no actual intent to hinder or delay creditors needs be proven.

Windsor Props., Inc. v. Dolphin Head Constr. Co., 331 S.C. 466, 470-71, 498 S.E.2d 858, 860 (1998).Â  When there are intra-family transfers, the law imposes a burden on the transferee to establish by clear and convincing evidence that there was both a valuable consideration and a bona fide transaction.Â  Id. at 471, 498 S.E.2d at 860-61.Â  
 
In Windsor, which involved a transfer of property from a husband to his wife, our supreme court found there was insufficient evidence of consideration where (1) the deed transferring the property recited there was â€œ[f]ive dollars and no other consideration,â€ but the attorney who prepared the deed could not recall money changing hands; and (2) the recipient testified consideration existed in the form of thousands of dollars advanced for the purchase, but there was no documentary evidence of these payments in the record other than a chart written by the recipient listing her alleged contributions.Â  Id. at 471-72, 498 S.E.2d at 860-61.
The supreme court noted the burden was on the recipient to establish the payment of valuable consideration.Â  Id. at 471, 498 S.E.2d at 860-61.Â  Moreover, the court stated the focus of the Statute of Elizabeth is on whether the grantor has reserved enough assets to satisfy his obligations, not just at the time of the transfer, but also at the time creditors are able to collect their indebtedness in full.Â  Id. at 473, 498 S.E.2d at 861-62; see also Gardner v. Kirven, 184 S.C. 37, 191 S.E. 814 (1937).
As the recipient of an intra-family transfer from her husband, the burden was on Charpia to establish the payment of valuable consideration within the meaning of the statute.Â  Although the deed to Charpia recited a consideration of $1.00 for the property transferred to her by her husband, by her own calculation, the property was worth anywhere from $140,000.00 to $150,000.00 and was not encumbered by a mortgage.Â  Charpia maintained she paid the dollar to her husband, but otherwise the transfer was a gift. Â Charpia acknowledged that the transfer left her husband with no substantial assets in his name.Â  In addition, both Charpia and her husband, as well as the attorney who prepared the deed, knew McMastersâ€™s lawsuit was pending at the time of the transfer.Â  We believe the only reasonable inference from the evidence is the conveyance was not supported by valuable consideration as required by the statute.Â  Further, the conveyance was voluntary and it left Charpiaâ€™s husband with no other assets to pay the obligation that had already accrued to McMasters (and was later reduced to judgment).
Based on the foregoing, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s determination the deed to Charpia should be set aside on the basis the conveyance was made in violation of the Statute of Elizabeth.Â  See Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002) (â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€); Dennis v. McKnight, 161 S.C. 209, 159 S.E. 555 (1931) (holding a complaint stated a cause of action for violation of the Statute of Elizabeth where a husband conveyed all of his property to his wife to secure the property in the event a judgment for wrongful death was later obtained against him); Albertson v. Robinson, 371 S.C. 311, 638 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 2006) (holding a husbandâ€™s transfer of the partiesâ€™ marital residence to his wife should be set aside pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth, even though the creditorsâ€™ claim had not been reduced to judgment at the time of the transfer; the husband made the transfer at the time the claim was pending, he lacked other funds to pay the debt, and the only reasonable inference was the stated consideration was insufficient); Mathis v. Brown, 319 S.C. 261, 460 S.E.2d 406 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating where a transfer is not supported by valuable consideration, it will be set aside pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth if the grantor was indebted to the creditor at the time of the conveyance, the conveyance was voluntary, and the grantor failed to retain sufficient assets to pay the indebtedness). 
 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In the caption of her complaint, McMasters stated the suit was against â€œCHARPIA RESIDENTIALS, LLC and HOWARD W. CHARPIA, Individually, DEFENDANT.â€Â  Throughout her complaint, McMasters referred to Charpia and his business singularly as the â€œdefendant.â€Â  Â Â 
[3] Charpiaâ€™s husband had previously filed a mechanicâ€™s lien for unpaid amounts McMasters allegedly owed on the home.Â 
 
[4]Â  Appellantâ€™s brief and the circuit courtâ€™s order state the judgment was obtained in 2005, but the judgment itself and all other references in the record are dated 2004.Â

title: B.W. Supply v. Summit Builders
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				B.W. Supply, Inc. d/b/a Johnstone Supply, Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Summit Builders, Inc., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Florence County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-191
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Wesley D. Peel, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				D. Malloy McEachin, Jr., of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Summit Builders, Inc. appeals the trial courtâ€™s determination that it is equitably estopped from asserting the defense of statute of limitations, arguing the trial court erred in failing to grant a directed verdict based on the applicable statute of limitations and finding it was equitably estopped from asserting such defense.Â  We affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS
On March 4, 1998, Summit Builders, as the general contractor, entered into a contract with Johnstone Supply, Inc. to construct a building in Murrellâ€™s Inlet, South Carolina.Â  Summit Builders began construction shortly thereafter, and work was completed on the building in the fall of 1999.Â  However, problems with the concrete floor began to surface in 1998.Â  A letter was sent on September 30, 1998, alerting Summit Builders that there was a problem with the concrete floor because there was too much organic material in it.Â  This problem was corrected shortly thereafter.Â 
 
However, additional problems with the concrete floor later developed.Â  Testimony showed that these problems were different than the problem corrected in 1998.Â  The later problems involved cracking and crumbling concrete making it unfit for its intended use.Â  There is conflicting evidence as to when these problems were discovered.Â  Some evidence showed these problems became noticeable in 2001.Â  Johnstone Supplyâ€™s Answers to Interrogatories stated that the problem at issue in the instant case was discovered sometime in 2000 by Jim Wood, a partner in Johnstone Supply.Â  At trial, Wood stated the problem began in 2001 but became a more serious issue in 2003.Â  However, in Woodâ€™s affidavit he indicates that the problem arose â€œin the spring or early summer of 2003.â€Â  The problems were mentioned to Summit Builders on several occasions and Summit Builders indicated that someone would take a look and see what needed to be done.Â  No repairs were ever made.Â  A letter dated June 5, 2003, noted that Johnstone Supply was making final payment but had concerns about the concrete floor.Â  The letter stated that final payment was only being made because of the warranty that had been provided.Â  Another letter dated August 5, 2003, indicated that the problem remained and requested Summit Builders make the repairs.Â 
 
On February 24, 2004, Johnstone Supply commenced this lawsuit against Summit Builders for breach of contract and breach of warranty.Â  A bench trial was held on December 5, 2005.Â  After hearing counselsâ€™ arguments and the testimony of witnesses, the trial court denied Summit Buildersâ€™ motion for a directed verdict based on the applicable statute of limitations.Â  The trial court denied the motion based on its findings that Summit Builders was equitably estopped from asserting a statute of limitations defense because of its actions in failing to fix the concrete problem when they were repeatedly asked to look at the problem.Â  It is unclear from the record whether the trial court felt the Complaint was filed beyond the statute of limitations.Â  This appeal followed.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Summit Builders argues the trial court erred in failing to grant a directed verdict based on the applicable statute of limitations.Â  However, in the record provided on appeal the only ruling of the trial court holds that Summit Builders was estopped from asserting the statute of limitations.[2]Â  Nowhere within the record before us is there a ruling by the trial court as to whether the statute of limitations had in fact expired on Johnstone Supplyâ€™s cause of action.Â  Summit Builders also contends the trial court erred in holding it was equitably estopped from asserting the defense of statute of limitations.Â  While the record indicates the trial judge ruled on the issue of estoppel, the record does not include the arguments raised by either party to the trial court.Â  Because of the deficiencies in the record before us, this court is unable to discern whether the trial judge ruled whether the statute of limitations had in fact expired, or whether the arguments advanced by Summit Builders on appeal were actually presented to the trial court.Â  Accordingly, we find these issues are not adequately preserved for review, and the record is insufficient to enable this court to make an intelligible review.Â  See In the Interest of Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (holding that issues must be raised and ruled upon in the trial court to be preserved for appellate review);Â  Taylor v. Taylor, 294 S.C. 296, 299, 363 S.E.2d 909, 911 (Ct. App. 1987) (providing â€œthe burden is on appellant to furnish a sufficient record on appeal from which this court can make an intelligent review.â€).
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED.Â  

HUFF, BEATTY, and CURETON, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] All that is provided in the record as to the trial courtâ€™s final determination are two pages from the trial transcript.Â  The two pages from the trial transcript provide the trial courtâ€™s ruling as to estoppel but do not contain the arguments raised to the trial court prior to its ruling.Â  Further, there is no final written order provided in the record before this court.

title: City of Columbia v. Faltas
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				City of Columbia, Respondent,
				v.
				Marie-ThÃ©rÃ¨se Assaâ€™ad-Faltas, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-193
Heard February 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 26, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Marie T. Assaâ€™ad-Faltas, of Columbia, Pro
				Se.
				Dana M. Thye, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Marie-ThÃ©rÃ¨se Assaâ€™ad-Faltas, M.D., M.P.H., appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to reverse the municipal courtâ€™s order granting her a new criminal trial.Â  We reverse.Â 
 
FACTS
On November 6, 2001, Faltas was arrested and charged with shoplifting after two Wal-Mart employees alleged they witnessed her remove several labels from multi-colored folders priced at $0.97 each.Â  The employees stated that Faltas replaced two labels on more expensive binders priced at either $4.97 or $3.97 each[1] with two of the $0.97 labels, and then she attempted to purchase the binders with the less expensive price labels on them.Â  A Polaroid photograph was purportedly taken of several multi-colored folders and the clear binders on the date of the incident.Â  Faltasâ€™s receipt showed that she purchased two â€œreport coversâ€ for $0.97 each with UPC numbers 007878799671.
 
A few weeks prior to trial, Faltasâ€™s attorney was made aware of the existence of the photograph.Â  He immediately sent a somewhat insulting letter to the City requesting that he have immediate access to the photograph.Â  The City responded in a short letter indicating that the case would be called for trial in two weeks and that Faltasâ€™s attorney could make any pre-trial motions.Â  No motions were made concerning the photograph, and neither Faltas nor her attorney gained access to the photograph prior to trial.Â 
 
On the date of the trial, Faltasâ€™s attorney moved to dismiss the shoplifting charge because:Â  the City did not have the original folders and binders from which Faltas was alleged to have switched labels; and the photograph of the purported items with switched labels mistakenly included the wrong binder, bringing into question whether Wal-Mart preserved the correct evidence.Â  The municipal court denied the motion to dismiss the charge and also denied Faltasâ€™s attorneyâ€™s motion to continue the case so he could appeal the denial of the motion to dismiss.[2]Â  The trial continued, with the City presenting the testimony of the two Wal-Mart employees who witnessed Faltas removing labels, the testimony of the arresting officer, and the introduction of the photograph.Â  According to a Wal-Mart employee who witnessed Faltasâ€™s actions, after the photograph was taken, the incorrect labels were removed from the binders and disposed of, and the binders were returned to the store shelves.Â  A police officer testified at trial that he saw the evidence against Faltas, including the photograph, prior to transporting Faltas to jail.Â 
 
Faltas testified at trial that she had previously returned two clear binders to Wal-Mart and had inadvertently attached the wrong labels to them prior to returning them.Â  When she was in Wal-Mart on the date of the incident, Faltas testified she decided to correct her error and switch the incorrect labels for correct labels.Â  She stated she actually switched less expensive labels for more expensive ones and that she went on to purchase completely different report covers with the appropriate labels attached.Â  Faltas was convicted of shoplifting and fined $500.Â  Her conviction was affirmed by both the circuit court and this court on appeal.Â  City of Columbia v. Faltas, Op. No. 2005-UP-00143 (S.C.Ct.App. dated Mar. 1, 2005).Â  On May 18, 2005, the case was remitted after the supreme court denied her petition for certiorari. Â 
Faltas moved before the municipal court for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence, and a hearing was held on May 23, 2005, before the same municipal judge who presided over her criminal trial.Â  Faltas had previously been allowed to make a copy of the photograph admitted into evidence during her trial.Â  Based on a digitally enlarged copy, she argued that the photograph was not taken at the time of her arrest but was instead fabricated by the Wal-Mart employees at a later time because, among other reasons: Â (1) stickers on the shelves in the background of the photograph were similar to the â€œNew Itemâ€ stickers used in 2002, indicating that the photograph was taken in 2002, not when Faltas was arrested in 2001; (2) the UPC symbols on the items in the photograph did not match the UPC symbols from the items she allegedly changed the labels on and purchased; and (3) the photograph was taken of items from the stationary aisle, not the arts and crafts aisle where Faltas obtained the binders she purchased.Â  Faltas also introduced Wal-Martâ€™s UPC manual that indicated that every item, including similar items of the same color, had a unique UPC symbol.Â  Because the folders shown in the photograph were of different colors, Faltas argued that the UPC numbers on the labels would have different numbers.Â  Thus, she argued, it was impossible that she took two labels from the different colored folders to put on the larger binders because her receipt showed she purchased two items with identical UPC numbers.Â  Â 
The municipal court issued an order granting Faltasâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  The municipal court found that Faltas â€œraised very serious and disturbing questions concerning the veracity of the testimony presented against her by the two Wal-Mart employees about the photograph.â€Â  The court noted that the photograph entered against her at her trial could not have been made at the time of her arrest because the â€œNew Itemâ€ stickers in the background were similar to the â€œNew Itemâ€ stickers Wal-Mart copyrighted in 2002.Â  The court found significant the fact that the colored folders would have two different UPC numbers and the items Faltas purchased had two identical UPC numbers.Â  The court found the evidence had been discovered after trial, and could not by due diligence have been discovered prior to trial, because Faltas was not allowed to review the photograph until trial and therefore could not have made the digital enlargement until after trial.Â  The court noted that where the original evidence was not retained and the City failed to make the photograph available to the defense until trial, despite Faltasâ€™s efforts to see it, â€œand where it is later shown that the photograph itself could not be what it has been purported by the prosecution to be, it may be said that the prosecutionâ€™s case is not merely impeached but thoroughly destroyed by the after discovered evidence.â€Â  The City appealed to the circuit court, arguing the municipal court made an error of law.
Faltas complained to the circuit court that the City did not have the right to appeal the order granting her a new trial.Â  The circuit court determined that the City did have the right to appeal and that the appeal was not interlocutory.Â  After reviewing the motion for a new trial, the transcript of the hearing, the evidence presented at the 2004 criminal trial, the briefs submitted by both parties, the affidavit of trial counsel, and the order granting a new trial, the circuit court concluded that the municipal courtâ€™s order was in error and reversed the grant of a new trial.Â  The circuit court determined that the physical evidence presented at the hearing on the new trial motion â€œdid not lead to the conclusive resultâ€ that the municipal court believed it did.Â  The circuit court found that Faltas had the opportunity at her criminal trial to challenge the photograph or request a continuance in order to further review the photograph, but she failed to do so.Â  Relying on the new trial standards set forth in State v. Caskey, 273 S.C. 325, 256 S.E.2d 737 (1979), the court held:Â  (1) the evidence would not likely change the result of the trial; (2) Faltas had the evidence available to her on the date of her trial, thus it was not discovered after trial; (3) the photograph could have been â€œdiscoveredâ€ prior to trial because Faltasâ€™s trial counsel was made aware of the existence of the photograph two weeks prior to trial; and (4) the evidence was merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  The circuit court determined that the municipal court committed an error of law in granting a new trial, reversed the municipal courtâ€™s order, and reinstated Faltasâ€™s conviction.Â  Faltas appeals.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.â€Â  State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2001); S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-25-105 (Supp. 2006) (â€œThere shall be no trial de novo on any appeal from a municipal court.â€).Â  Thus, as with any appeal of a criminal case, the circuit court, in its appellate capacity, sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  See State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (holding that appellate courts in criminal cases only review errors of law and are bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous).Â  This same scope of review applies to this court.Â  Id.; Henderson, 347 S.C. at 457, 556 S.E.2d at 692 (â€œIn reviewing criminal cases, this court may review errors of law only.â€).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Citing Anderson v. City of Bessemer City, 470 U.S. 564, 573-75 (1985),[3] for the proposition that appellate courts are not to determine the factual issues de novo, Faltas argues the circuit court erred in finding that the municipal courtâ€™s determination was clearly erroneous.Â  We agree that the circuit court employed the wrong standard of review.[4]
It is well-settled that the granting of a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court once the movant has made the requisite showing that the new evidence:Â  (1) would likely change the result if a new trial were granted; (2) was discovered since the trial; (3) could not have been discovered prior to trial by the exercise of due diligence; (4) is material to the issue of guilt or innocence; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  Caskey, 273 S.C. at 329, 256 S.E.2d at 738-39; see State v. Pierce, 263 S.C. 23, 31, 207 S.E.2d 414, 418 (1974) (noting that whether to grant a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion).
At the new trial hearing, Faltas:Â  submitted a digital enlargement of the photograph from trial; provided examples of Wal-Martâ€™s 2002 copyrighted â€œNew Itemâ€ stickers that were similar to the ones in the photograph; provided UPC codes from paper folders; described where the photograph was taken; and described the differences between the folders based on either angled or rounded edges or lack of outer clasps or prongs.Â  Faltas alleged that this evidence derived from the original photograph proved that the two Wal-Mart employees either were mistaken or that they fabricated their testimony and the photograph well after the date of her arrest.Â  Faltasâ€™s attorney also testified that, despite his repeated requests to see the photograph prior to trial, it was not provided to him.Â  Â Â Â 
The municipal court was convinced that the digital enlargement of the photograph, and the evidence that was obtained as a result of the digital enlargement, constituted after-discovered evidence because Faltas was denied access to the photograph by the City.Â  Thus, despite her attorneyâ€™s efforts to gain access to the photograph, Faltas could not have made the enlargement until after she was given access to the photograph after trial.Â  On appeal, the circuit court reviewed each piece of evidence introduced at the new trial hearing and made findings as to whether each piece of evidence was believable or supported the theory Faltas used it for.Â  The circuit court then performed a new analysis of the evidence pursuant to Caskey.Â  This was error.Â  Whether or not the circuit court agreed with the factual findings made by the municipal court, there was evidence presented at the new trial hearing to support the factual findings and the circuit court was bound by them.Â  
 
Thus, looking at the evidence, it was irrelevant that the circuit court would have ruled differently from the municipal court.Â  The circuit court was bound by the municipal courtâ€™s factual findings and the inferences to be drawn therefrom.Â  Its power was limited to determining whether the municipal court made an error of law in granting the new trial, based on the facts as found by the municipal court.Â  Because there were facts to support the municipal courtâ€™s legal analysis of the new trial motion, we find the circuit court erred in reversing the grant of the motion for a new trial.Â  We are likewise bound by the municipal courtâ€™s factual findings and must employ the same scope of review as the circuit court was bound to employ.Â  Applying this scope of review, we find there was evidence to support the municipal courtâ€™s findings, and thus, the municipal court did not abuse its discretion in granting the new trial motion.[5]
CONCLUSION
Because the circuit court erroneously conducted a de novo review of this matter, the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the municipal courtâ€™s grant of a new trial and reinstating Faltasâ€™s conviction is
 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The testimony is not clear as to whether the clear binders Faltas allegedly attempted to purchase were Plaid brand binders or Cardinal brand binders, each with a different price.
 
[2]Â  Faltas fired her attorney after he called two witnesses, and Faltas completed the trial pro se.Â  
 
[3]Â  Anderson, a United States Supreme Court case, discusses the appellate courtâ€™s role in federal cases to apply the clearly erroneous standard.Â  Anderson, 470 U.S. at 573-74 (â€œIf the . . . courtâ€™s account of the evidence is plausible in light of the record viewed in its entirety, the court of appeals may not reverse it even though convinced that had it been sitting as the trier of fact, it would have weighed the evidence differently.â€).Â  As previously discussed, our state court cases hold a similar scope of review for circuit courts reviewing the findings of the municipal court or master-in-equity.Â 
 
[4] Â Faltas also argues that the circuit court applied the wrong standard by relying upon State v. Caskey, 273 S.C. 325, 256 S.E.2d 737 (1979), in determining whether she was entitled to a new trial.Â  She asserts that State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 513 S.E.2d 98 (1999), effectively overruled Caskey, thus the circuit court relied upon the wrong standard.Â  Initially, it does not appear from the record that this matter was ever ruled upon by the circuit court.Â  This matter is not preserved for review.Â  State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (holding that an issue was not preserved for appellate review where it was not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court).Â  Further, both Spann and Caskey outline the five elements that a defendant must meet in order to obtain a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.Â  Thus, Spann does not overrule Caskey.Â  See Spann, 334 S.C. at 619-20, 513 S.E.2d at 99 (outlining the five elements for the granting of a new trial based on after-discovered evidence); Caskey, 273 S.C. at 329, 256 S.E.2d at 739 (same).
[5] Â Faltas raises numerous other arguments on appeal, including:Â  (1) the City was not entitled to appeal the grant of a new trial; (2) the appeal of the grant of a new trial violated the double jeopardy clause; (3) the City waived its grounds for appeal; (4) the circuit court erred by requiring her to file her brief simultaneously with the Cityâ€™s without allowing her to respond to the brief and without holding a hearing on the merits; (5) the circuit court erred by requiring her, as the winning party before the municipal judge, to preserve additional sustaining grounds for appeal; and (6) the circuit court erred in finding the photograph was not after-discovered evidence.Â  Because we reverse this case based on the scope of review, we need not address Faltasâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â
