title: State v. Fickens
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				George W. Fickens, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Colleton County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-194
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort; for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  George W. Fickens was convicted of felony driving under the influence (DUI) and sentenced to sixteen years imprisonment.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to suppress the blood alcohol test results because the State failed to:Â  (1) establish a complete chain of custody; (2) comply with the videotaping and affidavit requirements of South Carolina Code section 56-5-2953 (2006); and (3) comply with Fickenâ€™s discovery request for proficiency tests relating to the SLED toxicologist.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On June 30, 2004, Janette Dunn called the Highway Patrol to alert them that a small black car was weaving in and out of traffic on the westbound lane of Highway 63 near Walterboro and nearly sideswiped her car.Â  After Dunn drove into the median to avoid being hit by the small black car, she continued westbound on the road behind the car.Â  The small black car continued weaving in and out of traffic in the westbound lane before it rounded a curve in the road.Â  When Dunn rounded the same curve, she saw that the small black car had collided with a white car on the shoulder of the eastbound lane.Â  The driver of the white car, Rosa Dopson, was trapped in the vehicle and suffered serious injuries to her face and forehead.Â  She was transported to the Medical University of South Carolina where she later died from blunt force trauma to the head.Â  The driver of the small black car, Fickens, was also trapped under the steering wheel of his car and had to be extricated by emergency personnel.Â Â 
 
Lance Corporal Rich Riney of the South Carolina Highway Patrol was the first officer on the scene.Â  He testified that Fickensâ€™ passenger was unhurt but extremely intoxicated, and the passenger admitted to throwing a bottle of beer in the woods.[2]Â  Trooper Riney found two bottles of Budweiser in brown paper bags:Â  a mostly-consumed twenty-two ounce bottle on the driverâ€™s side floorboard and a freshly blood-stained bottle on the ground near Fickensâ€™ car.Â  According to Riney, Fickens smelled strongly of alcohol, his speech was slurred, and he was unable to communicate with anyone at the scene.Â  Paramedic Melissa Feathers, who treated Fickens at the scene, also testified that Fickensâ€™ clothes and breath smelled strongly of alcohol and Fickensâ€™s had slurred speech.Â Â 
 
Fickens was transported to the hospital where, at the direction of Trooper Riney, Nurse Shannon Mayes drew Fickensâ€™ blood.Â  A blood alcohol test showed that Fickensâ€™ blood alcohol level was .277 percent.Â  Fickens was later charged with felony DUI.Â  Over his objections, the results of Fickensâ€™ blood alcohol test were admitted at trial.Â  This appeal followed his conviction.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Chain of Custody
Fickens argues the trial court erred in admitting the blood alcohol test results because there was no evidence as to the identity of the person who took the blood evidence from Trooper Riney at the SLED headquarters and placed the evidence in the locked refrigerator.Â  Thus, Fickens argues, the State failed to establish a complete chain of custody.Â  We disagree.
 
Whether to admit or exclude evidence is a decision within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 566, 598 S.E.2d 279, 285 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The courtâ€™s decision to admit evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  Thus, this court looks to whether the trial courtâ€™s decision was controlled by an error of law or was without evidentiary support.Â  State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 23, 598 S.E.2d 735, 737 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIf there is any evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s decision, the appellate courts will affirm it.â€Â  Id. 
 
In order to admit blood or other fungible evidence, the State must prove a complete chain of custody, as far as practicable, tracing possession of the evidence from the time it was taken until the time it was analyzed.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 628-29, 614 S.E.2d 642, 646 (2005) (â€œWe have consistently held complete chain of evidence must be established as far as practicable, tracing possession from the time the specimen is taken from the human body to the final custodian by whom it is analyzed.â€); State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001) (â€œThe State must prove a chain of custody for a blood sample from the time it is drawn until it is tested.â€).Â  â€œThe evidence need not negate the most remote possibility of substitution, alteration, or tampering with the evidence, but rather must prove to a reasonable probability that the item is the same as, and not substantially different from, the object as it existed at the beginning of the chain.â€Â  Cochran, 364 S.C. at 629-30, 614 S.E.2d at 647.Â  Generally, our courts have found evidence inadmissible only where there is a missing link in the chain of possession because the identity of those who handled the blood was not established as far as practicable.Â  Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837; State v. Governor, 362 S.C. 609, 612, 608 S.E.2d 474, 475 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, our supreme court has recently noted that it has â€œnever held the chain of custody rule requires every person associated with the procedure be available to testify or identified personally, depending on the facts of the case.â€Â  Cochran, 364 S.C. at 629-30, 614 S.E.2d at 647.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
Nurse Shannon Mayes testified that she drew Fickensâ€™ blood in Trooper Rineyâ€™s presence, placed the blood into an uncontaminated vial, sealed the vial, and gave the vial to Trooper Riney.Â  Mayes stated she then witnessed Riney place the vial in an evidence box which he then sealed.Â  Trooper Riney testified that he witnessed Nurse Mayes draw Fickensâ€™ blood and seal and initial the vial.Â  Riney stated that after he received the vial from Mayes, he sealed it in an evidence box and then drove it to the locked evidence refrigerator at the Walterboro Highway Patrol office.Â  Sergeant Brown opened the lock so Riney could place the box in the refrigerator, and then Brown locked it again.Â  Riney testified that the following day Sergeant Brown unlocked the refrigerator so that Riney could retrieve the box and take it to the SLED laboratory in Columbia.Â  According to Riney, the box was in the same condition as it was when placed in the refrigerator and was still sealed.Â 
 
Riney stated that once at SLED headquarters in Columbia, a SLED technician took the evidence, unsealed the Styrofoam container in his presence, placed the still-sealed vial of blood in a heat-sealed bag, and sealed the bag in Rineyâ€™s presence.Â  The SLED technician then had Riney place his initials over the heat seal, and Riney placed the evidence in the locked refrigerator under the SLED technicianâ€™s supervision.Â  SLED toxicologist Laurie Shacker testified that the sealed evidence bag was brought to her by someone in the toxicology department from the locked refrigerator and that it was not tampered with in any way prior to her testing it.Â  Â 
Fickens objected to the admission of the blood alcohol test evidence, arguing the chain was not complete because the State did not present evidence of the identity of the person at SLED who took the evidence from the locked evidence refrigerator and gave it to Shacker.Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â Â 
 
Although the identity of the SLED technician who transported the sealed blood evidence to Shacker was not identified, we believe the State established a sufficient chain of custody, as far as practicable, such that it proved, to a reasonable probability, that the blood was â€œthe same as, and not substantially different from, the [blood] as it existed at the beginning of the chain.â€Â  Cochran, 364 S.C. at 629-30, 614 S.E.2d at 647.Â  The blood vial was sealed by Nurse Mayes, maintained in the Highway Patrolâ€™s locked evidence refrigerator, transported to SLED by Trooper Riney while still in its orginial sealed condition, placed in another heat-sealed evidence bag at SLED and then placed by Trooper Riney in the evidence refrigerator, and then obtained by Shacker, still in its sealed condition and un-tampered with.Â  Thus, the State reasonably established a complete chain of possession and that the evidence was still in the same condition when it was tested as it was when originally obtained from Fickens in the hospital.
 
Further, as previously discussed, our state supreme court has recently noted that, depending on the circumstances of a particular case, the failure to identify one person involved in the chain of custody may not render the evidence inadmissiable.Â  In Cochran, the Department of Social Services sought the termination of a motherâ€™s parental rights based, in part, on her failure of two drug tests.Â  Mother complained that DSS failed to establish a complete chain of custody over her blood samples because the identity of the courier who transported the blood from the collection site to the testing facility was unknown.Â  The court noted evidence was presented that the vials were sealed at the collection site and arrived at the testing facility still in a sealed condition.Â  Cochran, 364 S.C. at 629, 614 S.E.2d at 646.Â  The court also noted that every person involved in actually testing the blood testified as to their handling of the samples.Â  Id.Â  The court held that, generally, â€œwe will uphold the chain of custody if the safeguards instituted ensure the integrity of the evidence, even if every person associated with the procedure is not personally identified.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
Like the court in the Cochran case, we believe the particular facts in the present case show that the chain of custody was sufficiently established to negate the possibility of tampering and to show that the evidence arrived in the same condition for testing as it was when it was taken from Fickens.Â  Accordingly, we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit the blood evidence.Â 
 
II.  Section 56-5-2953
Fickens argues that because Trooper Riney failed to videotape the incident and failed to submit an affidavit explaining why he failed to videotape the incident, the blood evidence should have been suppressed.Â  We disagree.
Section 56-5-2953 provides that a person suspected of violating the DUI laws must have his conduct videotaped at the incident site and the breath test site.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(A) (2006).Â  The section further provides that:

	Nothing in this section may be construed as prohibiting the introduction of other evidence in the trial of a violation of [the DUI statutes.]Â  Failure by the arresting officer to produce the videotapes required by this section is not alone a ground for dismissal of any charge made pursuant to [the DUI statutes] if the arresting officer submits a sworn affidavit certifying that the videotape equipment at the time of the arrest, probable cause determination, or breath test device was in an inoperable condition, stating reasonable efforts have been made to maintain the equipment in an operable condition, and certifying that there was no other operable breath test facility available in the county or, in the alternative, submits a sworn affidavit certifying that it was physically impossible to produce the videotape because the person needed emergency medical treatment, or exigent circumstances existed. Further, in circumstances including, but not limited to, road blocks, traffic accident investigations, and citizensâ€™ arrests, where an arrest has been made and the videotaping equipment has not been activated by blue lights, the failure by the arresting officer to produce the videotapes required by this section is not alone a ground for dismissal. Â However, as soon as videotaping is practicable in these circumstances, videotaping must begin and conform with the provisions of this section. Â Nothing in this section prohibits the court from considering any other valid reason for the failure to produce the videotape based upon the totality of the circumstances; nor do the provisions of this section prohibit the person from offering evidence relating to the arresting law enforcement officerâ€™s failure to produce the videotape.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(B) (2006).Â   
At trial, Trooper Riney testified that he did not videotape the accident scene, nor did he submit an affidavit to explain the failure to videotape the scene.Â  Riney further testified that he could not have videotaped Fickens at the scene, considering: Â the position of Fickensâ€™ car after the accident; the fact that Fickens was trapped inside the car; and the inability to remove the patrol car camera and then take it to Fickensâ€™ car to film.Â  Fickens admitted before the trial court that although the remedy for the failure to videotape the incident â€œmay not be the dismissal of the case,â€ he argued that suppression of other evidence found at the scene, including the beer bottles and the testimony regarding the smell of alcohol, was warranted.Â  The trial court denied Fickensâ€™ motion.Â 
 
Initially, it does not appear that Fickensâ€™ argument is preserved for appellate review.Â  Although Fickens argued before the trial court that evidence found at the scene should be suppressed due Trooper Rineyâ€™s failure to comply with section 56-5-2953, Fickens did not argue the blood alcohol test evidence should be suppressed due to the failure to videotape the accident scene or submit an affidavit.Â  Thus, the argument that the blood alcohol test evidence should have been suppressed due to failure to comply with the statute was not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court and may not now be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review); Bryant v. Waste Mgmt., Inc., 342 S.C. 159, 171-72, 536 S.E.2d 380, 387 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that a party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal).Â  
 
In any event, we find Trooper Rineyâ€™s failure to comply with the videotaping and affidavit portions of the statute did not warrant suppression of the blood alcohol test evidence.Â  The statute provides that the failure to produce a videotape â€œis not alone a ground for dismissal of any charge.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(B) (2006).Â  Thus, a clear reading of the statute provides possible dismissal of the charge due to failure to comply with the statute.Â  Nothing in the statute, however, provides for suppression of evidence as a remedy when the State fails to comply with the statute.Â  In fact, the opening sentence in subsection B explicitly provides that the statute must not be construed to prohibit the introduction of other evidence of intoxication.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953(B) (2006).
 
Further, the statute allows the trial court to consider the totality of the circumstances in reviewing the arresting officerâ€™s failure to produce a videotape.Â  Id.Â  Reviewing the totality of the circumstances, there was evidence that Trooper Riney could not have videotaped Fickens based on the position of his car, the fact that Fickens was trapped in the car, and the fact that the camera was securely attached to Rineyâ€™s patrol car.Â  Considering the exigent nature of the accident and the other circumstances, we find Trooper Riney had a valid reason for failing to produce a videotape.Â  Â 
Even assuming the statute provides for exclusion of the blood alcohol evidence as a remedy for the Stateâ€™s failure to produce a videotape, we find the error would have been harmless.Â  Two witnesses saw Fickensâ€™ car weaving in and out of traffic prior to the accident.Â  Both Trooper Riney and the responding paramedic testified that Fickens smelled strongly of alcohol and was incoherent.Â  Two twenty-two ounce beer bottles were found on the scene.Â  Despite the fact that Fickens was driving in the westbound lane, the accident occurred with both Fickensâ€™ and the victimâ€™s cars off the shoulder in the eastbound lane.Â  This evidence would reasonably support Fickensâ€™ conviction for felony DUI without the blood alcohol evidence.Â  Thus, any error in admitting the blood alcohol evidence is harmless.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (holding that an error is harmless when it could not have reasonably affected the outcome of the trial).
III.Â  Failure to comply with discovery requests
Fickens argues that the State failed to provide the proficiency tests of SLED toxicologist Shacker pursuant to Fickensâ€™ Brady[3] motion.Â  Fickens asserts the trial court should have conducted a hearing because he made the threshold showing that the proficiency tests were material.Â  Therefore, Fickens argues, the trial court erred in admitting the blood alcohol evidence.Â Â  We disagree.Â 
 
To comply with a Brady request for disclosure of exculpatory evidence, the State must disclose both impeachment and exculpatory evidence favorable to a defendant which is material to guilt or punishment.Â  United States v. Bagley, 473 U.S. 667, 676 (1985); State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 241, 471 S.E.2d 689, 693 (1996).Â  â€œEvidence is material under Brady if there is a reasonable probability that had the evidence been disclosed, the result of the proceeding would have been different.â€Â  State v. Proctor, 358 S.C. 417, 421, 595 S.E.2d 476, 478 (2004).Â  Once a defendant makes the threshold showing that the evidence he seeks is material, the trial court should conduct a hearing.Â  Id. at 422, 595 S.E.2d at 478.Â  â€œFor Brady purposes, in determining the materiality of nondisclosed evidence, an appellate court must consider the evidence in the context of the entire record.â€Â  State v. Talyor, 333 S.C. 159, 177, 508 S.E.2d 870, 879 (1998). Â The court should not consider the sufficiency of the evidence, and it should only consider whether the appellantâ€™s right to a fair trial was impaired.Â  Proctor, 358 S.C. at 423, 595 S.E.2d at 479.Â  

We initially note that this argument is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Fickens complained to the trial court that, although he filed a discovery request for Shackerâ€™s proficiency tests, the State failed to turn them over to him.Â  Fickens argued that it rendered him unable to adequately cross-examine Shacker, and thus the blood test results should be suppressed.Â  Fickens never argued the failure to turn over the proficiency tests amounted to a Brady violation.Â  He also did not argue the tests were material or request a Brady hearing.Â  Thus, the Brady issue before us was never raised to or ruled upon by the trial court and is raised for the first time on appeal.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546 (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review); Bryant, 342 S.C. at 171-72, 536 S.E.2d at 387 (holding that a party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal).Â  
 
Even assuming the Brady issue was adequately presented to the trial court, we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s actions.Â  Nothing in the record indicates that the State ever had possession of Shackerâ€™s proficiency tests or what Shackerâ€™s proficiency scores were.Â  Thus, it is impossible to determine whether the proficiency scores were material to Fickensâ€™ defense.Â  Nevertheless, Fickens was able to adequately cross-examine Shacker regarding the procedures used during the blood sample collection and testing.Â  Further, in light of all the other evidence presented at trial, we find any error in failing to suppress the alcohol blood tests due to an alleged Brady violation by the State would be harmless.Â  Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151 (holding that an error is harmless when it could not have reasonably affected the outcome of the trial); see Proctor, 358 S.C. at 424, 595 S.E.2d at 480 (finding that the nondisclosure of DNA proficiency test results was not material considering the fact that the other evidence was â€œformidableâ€). Â Â 
Accordingly, we find Fickensâ€™ right to a fair trial was not impaired and we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit the blood alcohol test results.
 
CONCLUSION
Because the trial court did not err in failing to suppress Fickensâ€™ blood alcohol test results, Fickensâ€™ conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â The passenger was arrested for violating the open container law, littering, and public drunkenness.Â Â 
 
[3] Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).

title: Doe v. Rojas
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John and Jane Doe, as Parents, Natural Guardians and Next Friends of Anonymous Child, Appellants,
				v.
				Cassius Rojas and Richland County School District #2, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-195
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed April 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John E. Schmidt, III and Melissa J. Copeland, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
				James Shadd, III, Kathryn Long Mahoney, Thomas K. Barlow and Kenneth L. Childs, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this tort action, John and Jane Doe[1] (the Does) appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Richland County School District Two (the School District) on their claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
During the 2001-2002 school year, the School District employed Cassius Rojas as a teacher.Â  Rojas taught math and coached the girlsâ€™ basketball team at Ridge View High School (Ridge View).Â  The Doesâ€™ minor daughter, KK, was a junior at Ridge View and manager of the girlsâ€™ basketball team. Â She was also Rojasâ€™ student aide.Â  At some point during the school year, Rojas and KK began to have a sexual relationship.Â  The two had sex on numerous occasions and often had sex while at Ridge View.Â 
 
On July 29, 2002, while at a coachesâ€™ convention, Rojas confided to Coach Lynch, who was also employed at Ridge View, that he was having sex with a junior at the school.Â  Lynch, believing Rojasâ€™ confession to be â€œthe ramblings of a drunken man,â€ did not inform school officials until August 20, after the School District had discovered Rojasâ€™ misconduct.Â  
 
On August 16, 2002, around lunchtime, a student who was home changing clothes saw Rojas leaving KKâ€™s house.Â  KK lived near the school and was on â€œhomeboundâ€ status at the time.Â  When the student returned to school, he reported the information to the schoolâ€™s assistant principal.Â  Principal Sharon Buddin confronted Rojas, who initially denied being at KKâ€™s house.Â  Rojas averred he left his keys at the front desk of the school and went jogging in order to find a jogging route for the girlsâ€™ basketball team.Â  Although the jogging route took him by KKâ€™s residence, he denied going to the house.Â  According to KK, , Rojas called later that day to tell her Principal Buddin would be calling to discuss the allegations against him.Â  Rojas explained KK should lie and tell Principal Buddin he was not at her house.Â  On August 19, after repeatedly denying Rojasâ€™ presence at her house, KK eventually broke down in tears and confessed to a school guidance counselor.Â Â 
 
On August 20, 2002, the School District placed Rojas on administrative leave pending the outcome of an investigation.Â  Soon after, officers arrested Rojas and he formally resigned from his teaching and coaching positions at Ridge View.Â  
 
In 2000, prior to the Rojas incident, another coach at Ridge View was accused of having a sexually inappropriate relationship with a female student.Â  During the same year, an administrator at the school was reprimanded for touching a studentâ€™s legs when demonstrating proper short lengths and for grabbing student IDs off studentsâ€™ chests instead of asking the students to hand over their IDs.Â Â  
 
On August 5, 2004, the Does and KK filed suit against the School District.[3]Â  The parties agreed to settle all of KKâ€™s claims, leaving only the Doesâ€™ claims against the School District.Â  On June 20, 2005, the School District moved for summary judgment on the Doesâ€™ claims for intentional infliction of emotional distress and negligent supervision. Â 
After a hearing on January 10, 2006, the trial court found the Does failed to identify any conduct by the School District so extreme and outrageous, that it exceeded all possible bounds of decency.Â  Accordingly, the trial court granted summary judgment to the School District on the intentional infliction of emotional distress claim.Â  However, the trial court denied the School Districtâ€™s motion with respect to the Doesâ€™ negligent supervision claim. This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  Both the trial court and appellate courts apply the same standard when reviewing a summary judgment motion pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP: Â summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002). Â The evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 494, 567 S.E.2d at 860.Â  
 
The party moving for summary judgment has the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, and the non-moving party must show more than the allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Peterson v. W. Am. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 94, 518 S.E.2d 608, 610 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The non-moving party must come forward with specific facts showing a genuine issue for trial.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 660, 582 S.E.2d 432, 438 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Does allege the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on their claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress was an error of law.Â  The Does maintain the trial court erred in finding the School Districtâ€™s behavior was not extreme and outrageous.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina has long recognized â€œthat â€˜oneâ€™s wilful, malicious conduct proximately causing anotherâ€™s emotional distress may be actionableâ€™ as intentional infliction of emotional distress or the tort of outrage.â€Â  Williams v. Lancaster Sch. Dist., 369 S.C. 293, 305, 631 S.E.2d 286, 293 (Ct. App. 2006) (quoting Ford v. Hutson, 276 S.C. 157, 161, 267 S.E.2d 776, 778 (1981)).Â  To establish a claim for intentional infliction of distress, or outrage, a party must show: 
 

	(1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress or was certain or substantially certain that such distress would result from his conduct . . . ; (2) the conduct was so â€œextreme and outrageousâ€ as to exceed â€œall possible bounds of decencyâ€ and must be regarded as â€˜atrocious, and utterly intolerable in a civilized communityâ€™ . . . ; (3) the actions of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was â€œsevereâ€ so that â€œno reasonable man could be expected to endure it.â€

Folkens v. Hunt, 290 S.C. 194, 203, 348 S.E.2d 839, 844 (Ct. App. 1986) (quoting Ford, 276 S.C. at 162, 276 S.E.2d at 778)).Â  
 
The determination of â€œwhether a defendantâ€™s conduct may be reasonably regarded as so extreme and outrageous as to allow recovery is a question for the court to determine in the first instance.â€ Â Butts v. AVX Corp., 292 S.C. 256, 262-63, 355 S.E.2d 876, 880 (Ct. App. 1987); see Andrews v. Piedmont Air Lines, 297 S.C. 367, 371, 377 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1989) (noting that question of whether a defendantâ€™s conduct may be reasonably regarded as so extreme and outrageous as to permit recovery for intentional infliction of emotional distress is question for the trial court to determine). Â After the initial showing is made that â€œconduct is shown which may be reasonably regarded as extreme and outrageous,â€ the matter should be submitted to the jury to determine â€œwhether the conduct complained of is, in fact, sufficiently extreme and outrageous to result in liability.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 338 S.C. 524, 537, 526 S.E.2d 732, 739 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002).Â  
 
With these considerations in mind, we turn to the case at hand.Â  To support their claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress, the Does contend they suffered severe emotional distress due to the School Districtâ€™s failure to: Â (1) provide appropriate sexual harassment training to staff, students, and parents; and (2) follow mandatory federal guidelines.Â  
 
On the outset, we observe the Doesâ€™ arguments are not preserved for review.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
 
Although the Does allege in their memorandum in opposition to summary judgment that the School District failed to follow federal guidelines and failed to provide appropriate sexual harassment training to staff, these issues were argued as part of the Doesâ€™ claim for negligence.Â  The Does did not raise these arguments in either their memorandum or at the hearing with respect to their claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  The trial court, in summarily denying the School Districtâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to the Doesâ€™ claim for negligence, presumably found the arguments persuasive on the issue of the School Districtâ€™s negligence.Â  However, it is clear from the trial courtâ€™s order that it did not consider these arguments with respect to the claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order only refers to the Doesâ€™ allegations that the School District failed to provide them with written reports and failed to prevent Rojasâ€™ misconduct.Â  Thus, the trial court did not rule on the issues with regard to the claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Additionally, the Does failed to make any Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  Therefore, the issues are not preserved for our review on appeal.Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to amend, the issue is not properly presented to an appellate court for review).Â  Accordingly, we decline to address the Doesâ€™ points of error on the above mention grounds.
The Does also contend the School Districtâ€™s failure to act preemptively to prevent the harm which occurred constituted extreme and outrageous behavior.Â  Specifically, the Does point to the School Districtâ€™s failure to follow school policies which they believe, if followed, would have prevented the abuse and the School Districtâ€™s failure to make any changes following the two sexual harassment incidents that preceded the Rojas incident.Â  The Does also argue the School Districtâ€™s actions after the Rojas incident occurred constituted extreme and outrageous behavior.Â  They allege that because the School District failed to act in a timely manner, upon Coach Lynchâ€™s knowledge of Rojasâ€™ sexual harassment, Rojas was able to further victimize KK.Â  They also argue the School District failed to appropriately discipline administrators for failing to prevent the abuse.Â  Additionally, they contend the School Distract failed to provide them with written follow-up reports in accordance with school policy. The Does maintain these failures constituted extreme and outrageous behavior on the part of the School District for which they are entitled to recover.
South Carolina law limits claims of intentional infliction of emotional distress to egregious conduct toward a plaintiff proximately caused by the defendant.Â  See Upchurch v. N.Y. Times Co., 314 S.C. 531, 536, 431 S.E.2d 558, 561 (1993) (â€œIt is not enough that the conduct is intentional and outrageous.Â  It must be conduct directed at the plaintiff, or occur in the presence of a plaintiff of whom the defendant is aware.â€).Â  We note the record contains no evidence that the School District, in failing to take any preemptive action to prevent the abuse, targeted or directed any of its conduct towards the Does.Â  Further, no evidence suggests the School Districtâ€™s actions after discovering Rojasâ€™ misconduct was directed towards the Does.
Moreover, even if the School Districtâ€™s actions could be construed as being directed toward the Does, we find the Does have not presented any factual allegations of the type of extreme or outrageous conduct committed by the School District that gives rise to a claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Viewed in a light most favorable to the Does, the School Districtâ€™s behavior in this instance is not sufficiently severe to rise to the level of conduct considered â€œso extreme and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency [that] must be regarded as atrocious and utterly intolerable in a civilized community.â€Â  Upchurch, 314 S.C. at 536, 431 S.E.2d at 561.Â  The Does have shown â€œno hostile or abusive encounters, or coercive or oppressive conduct.â€Â  Gattison v. S.C. State College, 318 S.C. 148, 157, 456 S.E.2d 414, 419 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding although plaintiff alleged â€œunprofessional, inappropriate behavior,â€ the defendantâ€™s conduct did not exceed all possible bounds of decency).Â Â Â  
 
While it is still to be determined whether the School District may have acted negligently in failing to follow certain policies, or by failing to make changes after the two prior incidents, the record fails to reveal any conduct by the School District that was so extreme or outrageous that would enable the Does to survive summary judgment.Â  See Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 401, 596 S.E.2d 42, 49 (2004) (finding while staff arguably may have acted negligently in failing to follow policies, the staff did not act â€œrecklessly or intentionally in the extreme or outrageous manner described in the complaintâ€).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment as to the Doesâ€™ claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.[4]
CONCLUSION
We hold the Does have no viable cause of action for intentional infliction of emotion distress because the Does failed to allege any conduct directed towards them that is sufficiently extreme and outrageous on the part of the School District to allow recovery.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â It is difficult to discern from the record who the appellants are in this case.Â  After reviewing the order and the record, it appears KK has settled all her individual claims.Â  Therefore, her parents are the only parties appealing.Â 
 
[2]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]  The complaint is not included in the Record on Appeal.
[4]  In light of our disposition of this case, we need not reach the issue of whether the Tort Claims Act is a statutory bar to a cause of action for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
